dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sir, the writer is here from the PR Department.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Set him up a typewriter in my outer office... and show him my photos of A. Mitchell Palmer. INT. ATTORNEY GENERAL PALMER’S HOME / LIBRARY - 1919 - NI A tall, strong, square jawed man in his late 40's, A. MITCHELL PALMER, sits in the downstairs library of his fo story townhouse on R street, a posh DC neighborhood in 19

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Attorney General Palmer was a Quaker. He didn’t believe in war. But he understood the necessity of strength and resolve. Believe-- Palmer watches his WIFE pad quietly up the stairs. He che a clock against his watch and corrects the minute hand. 1 INT. ATTORNEY GENERAL PALMER’S HOME / BEDROOM - MOMENTS L Palmer undresses, but instead of joining his wife in bed, clicks on a lamp by a chair and settles in with a book.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --what you will from historians. Most write from a present perspective, forgetting context. Mitchell Palmer was a hero.  Palmer looks to a window, listening to the WHIR OF A MOTORCAR, the HORSE HOOVES ON THE COBBLESTONES. He goes b to reading ignoring the new sounds outside: A CAR PULLS U

dialogues.speaker: THE WALLS CRACK, GLASS SHATTERS, FURNITURE GOES FLYING
dialogues.text: Palmer is hurled from his chair, his wife thrown from her bed. Palmer lifts himself off the floor, rushes to his wi and pulls her out of the room. INT. ATTORNEY GENERAL PALMER’S HOME / STAIRS - CONTINUOUS They race down the twisted, crumbling stairs. Palmer fall through a broken step, pulls himself back up, and wills t to a bedroom door where a GIRL CAN BE HEARD SCREAMING. The door frame has buckled, but its no match for Palmer’s brute strength. He throws his body against the door, revealing his TEEN DAUGHTER crying hysterically, the elec lights flickering on and off. His wife runs to her side. Everything is suddenly silent. Palmer cautiously navigate what remains of the stairs. Around any corner is a potent assassin. A sudden crash! An assailant? He braces himself pulls a banister rung off to use as a weapon. As he turns the corner to the ground floor, he finds utte destruction: A STUFFED ELKS HEAD thrown to the floor, par flooring ripped to pieces, piles of rubble, and everywher SPOTS OF FRESH BLOOD starting to drip down the walls. He looks to where his front wall and windows once were. O on the street a car has blown over. And piercing the sile

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Palmer? Palmer rushes beside the mantle for protection, but its bricks crumble to the floor. Stepping into the cavernous remains of the home is a 30-y old version of future president FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT wit braces on his legs and a crutch. Behind him, lifting her skirt to avoid stepping on the hem is a young ELEANOR.

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Roosevelt? Thank Thee. Thank thee Lord it’s you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man, 24, burst out the door of a modest two story home in a simple suit, holding a bike. He’s built like a plug with wavy black hair, attractive in a bulldogish way He hops on his bike and peddles determinedly, stopping at each intersection like a model citizen, then peddling his heart out again. This is young JOHN EDGAR HOOVER.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Across the country, eight bombs exploded that night. All at 11PM. Two United States Senators, four cabinet members, a Supreme Court Justice, John D. Rockerfeller, J.P. Morgan. All of them targeted. As he rides out of frame, REVEAL: only a few blocks away, dome of the US Capital peaks over the tops of the working class homes. Further in the distance puffs of smoke and flames. The city is in turmoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a single window on the block survived the blast. Tree limbs are down. Cars are on their sides. The block is lit with flood lights. Detectives and reporters swarm. Police push neighbors back, roping off the neighborhood. A LONG POV: Mitchell Palmer’s giant shoe steps through th wreckage, almost crushing a severed finger lying in the street. He is flanked by young Roosevelt and another up a coming neighbor, young DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER.

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: This may be the end of days for this country, Dwight. Palmer picks up the finger without putting on a glove, an hands it to an INSPECTOR who puts it in a TRASH TIN. REVEAL: this is all young Edgar’s POV. He is on his bike behind the police ropes watching the investigators carele sweep up evidence: two guns, remains of a suitcase, an English/Italian dictionary. IN A MANNER THAT WILL BECOME A TRADEMARK OF THE FILM: we what Edgar sees: a brief imagined STRING OF LIGHT connect the severed finger to A BLOWN OPEN BRIEFCASE. He’s making connections. Organizing. But the strings vanish when the inspectors use buckets t CLEAN UP THE BLOOD instead of collecting it. It’s not clu it’s customary. This isn’t 2009, it’s 1919. Still, Edgar disturbed by the vanishing connections. Suddenly, a gust of wind shakes the trees and reveals hundreds of PINK HAND-BILLS in the road. Their festive co stands in stark contrast to the destruction. Edgar gather any that blow past the police line. He reads one. We hear

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “There will have to be BLOODSHED: there will have to be MURDER: we will KILL because it is necessary: we will destroy to rid the world of your tyrannical institution.” ANGLE ON: Palmer notices Edgar collecting the fliers.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is he a neighbor, sir? Should we question him?

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: No. He works in my office.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is he an investigator?

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: He manages the filing system. And without knowing he’s been spotted, Edgar jumps back o his bike and peddles away holding the BRIGHT PINK FLIERS.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You were at Attorney General Palmer’s home that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera cruises down the halls of the “MODERN” FBI. Th agents are dressed to perfection. Everything is in its pl

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Leave that to the reader’s imagination. It’s important to give the protagonist a bit of mystery. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - SAME TIME A handsome, clean cut young FBI agent, AGENT SMITH, sits behind a 60’s typewriter taking notes on a pad of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could allude to a young man whose description matches yours. The best of both worlds. REVEAL: standing across the room behind a mahogany desk i stout old man with a mashed in nose wearing a three piece suit and holding one of those OLD PINK FLIERS from 1919. is Hoover, almost 40 years later, now J. EDGAR HOOVER. He lets out a laugh that leaves behind a smile. He isn’t the brute he’s come to be known as. He’s surprisingly warm.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where did you get your law degree?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: George Washington. I grew up here. I had a mom to take care of, so I stayed close. I received an English degree there as well. Hoover walks behind him, reads out of his typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Then I don’t have to tell you that what determines a legacy is often what isn’t seen... What’s critical at this moment is that we RE- clarify the difference between villain and hero. How do you think that compares with today? The young man winds the paper out of the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, sir. I’d like to hear more. I could come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Fine. The pages stay here though.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Hoover grabs the young agent’s hand and shakes it, holdin a bit longer than normal. The agent knows he’s being size up. He goes, taking his typewriter with him. Left alone, Hoover inspects the hand he just shook with. PERFECTLY DRY. It WAS a test and Hoover seems pleased. He puts the OLD PINK FLIER back in an ancient file folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Edgar walks down the long hall (same as earlier, bu years earlier) with a staccato gate in a crisp white shir holding that same (but brand new) file with THE PINK FLIE A GAGGLE OF SECRETARIES, dresses to the floor, are headed right toward him. Most are far older than him.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Good morning, John. Mr. Palmer has asked that you attend the emergency meeting today.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s Mr. Hoover, please.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Two o’clock. Don’t be too early again. It’s as rude as being tardy. She bustles off with the rest, but not before a slim, you secretary, 22, with dark hair, lovely eyes, and a high collar makes eye contact with him. Edgar isn’t shy.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: And who is this lovely addition to the secretarial pool?

dialogues.speaker: HEAD SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Helen, introduce yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Mr. Hoover. I’m Helen Gandy.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Department of Justice, Miss. Gandy... Please let Mr. Palmer know I will attend. As if he had any choice in the matter. The secretaries br off, mocking his attempt at grandiosity. Edgar shares one last glance with Helen before she vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packards, Model Ts, bikes and horse drawn coaches rumble Edgar’s trolly, all sharing the cobblestone streets. IT’S THE MIDDLE OF THE D.C. RACE RIOTS: Smoke drifts from business a block down. The trolly keeps pace with OFFICER chasing a BLACK MAN. But as they reach an intersection, t  police are greeted with a CROWD OF OTHER BLACK MEN. The police are overwhelmed. Edgar watches like it’s a play, refusing to let it dampen his mood. EXT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - LATER As Edgar approaches the house, he spots a GRAY-HAIRED, EMACIATED MAN rocking manically on the porch in a wicker chair. Edgar steels himself and climbs the steps. As soon as the old man spots Edgar, he starts SCREAMING BLOODY MURDER. Edgar ignores it, he won’t let this ruin h cheerful mood either. He walks into his house. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - CONTINUOUS As Edgar walks in, he sees his MOTHER, a stout, outgoing, opinionated woman bent over, tuning the radio, her giant side to him. It’s all he sees. A FLASH-- INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - (IN HIS MIND / MEMORY) Edgar sits at his mother’s feet. She pets him like a chil HOOVER’S MOTHER Madame Marcia held court this morning. Her premonition... I should buy a dress. She said your father will die soon, and when he does, you will rise to be the most powerful man in the country. Your brother is a good man, EDGAR, but you will restore our family to greatness. EDGAR-- He looks up with childlike fear. Her “Edgar's” cross the INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME —- NIGHT In reality, Edgar is sitting by the radio with his Mother EDGAR’S MOTHER --Edgar? Am I boring you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m listening. You fired the maid. EDGAR’S MOTHER I told her after she was through with her work, she could quit as I was not paying for her impudence. The whole Negro race is in open revolt.  YOUNG HOOVER EDGAR’S MOTHER I could open an They’ve gotten too investigation. comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? I said I could open an investigation. EDGAR’S MOTHER Say what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (beaming) Mr. Palmer called me into a meeting today. The war against the radicals has begun. He insisted that I lead a new Anti-Radical division. EDGAR’S MOTHER (skeptical) And did you leap like a dog?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I told him, “This is perhaps the greatest threat our nation has ever faced. I can NOT take the job... unless I feel certain I can be effective.” EDGAR’S MOTHER Well done! But you’ll take it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Three thousand a year. EDGAR’S MOTHER I’ll have to get you all new clothes! You can’t dress like this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I have forty names of suspected radicals already, in only four hours. I’1l have ten thousand by the end of the month. And I have my own staff. Trusted agents. EDGAR’S MOTHER (critical) Are you smoking, Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ashamed) It doesn’t come naturally. EDGAR’S MOTHER Listen to the doctor. With this new burden, your nerves could get the best of you. You don’t want to end up like your father. Go try one now. You can put your father in his room.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I have to get ready for dinner. EDGAR’S MOTHER You’re abandoning me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s with a typist. She’s very organized. EDGAR’S MOTHER Is it a date?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I think so... I’m going to show her my old card catalogue system at the library of Congress. EDGAR’S MOTHER (disappointed, critical) Card catalogues, Edgar? And with that, the screen door opens and Edgar’s emaciate father walks in and down to the basement without saying a word. Both pretend not to see or hear him. She leaps up a heads to the basement door. EDGAR’S MOTHER (CONT'D) Romance her. Wear a blue tie. You look so handsome in that blue tie! And she slams the basement door shut, trapping her crazy husband downstairs. She seemed downright jolly about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar (in his blue tie) and Helen are surrounded by THOUS OF BOOKS AND SHELVES, standing in front of a MASSIVE FILI SYSTEM in the dimly lit, breathtaking heart of the Librar It’s romantic, clandestine. The only other person there i NIGHT GUARD well in the distance.  10.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I helped develop it. You see, each item is assigned an index card with a completely unique code indicating its topic, title, author, and location. What took days to locate, now takes minutes. Name a topic, or an author. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Indiscretion.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What era?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Present day.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Time me. Edgar dives into the catalogue system. Much like the bloo and briefcase at the Palmer house bombing, we see this se through Edgar’s mind. The same LIT STRINGS appear momenta sending him to one row of files, then one column, then on specific file. LIT STRINGS appear and evaporate with the splendor of lightening bugs on a southern summer. He pulls out a single card and flashes it to Helen. She giggles. He leads her in his speedy way to a towering row book cases. LIT STRINGS ARE EVERYWHERE, all leading to a single book. He pulls it out: CONTEMPORARY COURTSHIP.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: (teasing) How do you know I didn’t mean POLITICAL indiscretion?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: If you’d like to start over, we can.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: No. This will do.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: How long did I take?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: One minute, ten seconds.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Imagine if every citizen in the country was uniquely identifiable (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: with their own card and number. Say, the pattern on their fingers. Imagine how quickly they could be found when they committed a crime. He re-files the book, clearly missing that she’s been flirting. She’s a little disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: It’s all very impressive, John.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... Should we go?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: It’s up to you. He knows what he needs to do. And with his hands at his s he leans in for a kiss. It’s awkward. Like a school boy.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Did I do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: No. But I’m not sure where you think this is headed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. And with the precision of an army cadet, he gets down on knee and grabs hold of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss. Gandy, despite the brief time we’ve known each other, I feel assured that you would make a fine companion. Your strength, your character, your education--

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Are you poking fun at me?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Please stand up, Mr. Hoover.  12.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (he does, humiliated) I would appreciate it if you didn’t share this with the other women in the typing pool.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Would you mind telling me wh-wh-wh- what fl-- (speeds up to kill the stutter) flaw you’ve found in my character?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: No. We just met.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (speedy, defensive) of course. But I’m a fast and accurate judge of character. We’ve gone out three times. Many people do, but I don’t. It’s my most treasured skill. I see people right off for what they are. And please, call me Edgar. It’s what my mother uses.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Edgar, can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You have my word.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: I have no interest in getting married. My work comes first.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (bruised) I see... Then perhaps you’1l consider the position of personal secretary for the new radical division. In this moment of need... for our country. That’s a proposal she can accept. He fights back the humiliation, chin up, and makes a bee line out of there. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - 1963 This is Hoover’s small private office. A RED BUZZER rings his desk. He glares at it. It buzzes again.  13.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Miss Gandy! And an OLD HELEN GANDY walks in carrying files. OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) The nitwit Kennedy child rang his baby buzzer again. Perhaps he needs a fresh diaper. Hoover takes her files and neatly orders them into his private cabinet. He locks it back.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Would you like me to find out what the Attorney General needs?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I would like you to finish the transcript from the Los Angeles recording. When you’re done, we’ll answer his buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Okay... Edgar? Agent Smith is back. He has questions about the Palmer raids. Should I tell him to go?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (lights up) No... Do you like him, Helen?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: I don’t have an opinion of him yet.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I like him. I trust him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: I’1ll set him up in your outer office.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. Set him up a desk in here. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - 1964 Hoover is bright and cheery again as he spins a tale in h rapid pace for the young FBI agent who sits typing away.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: In 1920 we had no federal laws, no power, no firearms, and Congress (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: liked it that way. The criminals ran free. But there was no law against keeping track of radicals. I compiled note cards on over 5000 names. And called the one Department that held a small piece of untested power.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: The Department of Labor. The power to deport, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: But only to deport people who checked two boxes. They had to be foreign citizens. AND, they had to be working to harm the country.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FBI MAN
dialogues.text: The Labor Department cooperated?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Of course not. No one freely shares power in Washington DC, Agent Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Edgar sits behind Palmer who shakes EDGAR’S NOTE CA bearing names of suspected radicals. Edgar is in awe as h Mentor rants to the heads of the Labor Dept., ABERCROMBIE CAMINETTI, and their young LABOR DEPARTMENT LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me there is no law under which YOU can issue a warrant for the arrest of an alien when I certify that he is subject to deportation?!

dialogues.speaker: LABOR DEPT LAWYER
dialogues.text: Without evidence, Mr. Attorney General? No! There exists a Due process of law, sir!

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL PALMER
dialogues.text: Due process of law? What about the threat to our country!? Edgar looks to an old man in the corner, CAMINETTI. A FRE FRAME OF: EDGAR’S POV OF CAMINETTI’S UNFLATTERING SCOWL:

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But one of their heads, A Mr. Caminetti... well, he WAS wary of (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: our Justice Department, but he hated one person more--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fiery, stout woman (hair up, glasses on her nose) stand stage shaking her fist at a crowd of 3000 red-banner wavi slogan chanting Russians, Jews, Fins, Poles, Italians...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I am a revolutionist by nature and temperament and as such I claim the right to rebel and resist invasion by all means, force included, consequently, a destructionist! From a balcony, Edgar listens, jotting down notes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Emma Goldman, hero of the radical movement. She was set to be released from prison in two weeks. If I could hand CAMINETTI, Emma Goldman, he’d deport her without a thought. We’d have our precedent... INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - 1963

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: But she was a citizen, sir. Hoover has gone silent. He’s focused on his frosted glass steel back door. He watches the SILHOUETTE OF AN OLD MAN past and pause. He waits, breathless. The figure limps aw The sound of a door beyond his opens and closes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FBI MAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to stop, sir?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: No... It’s hard for you to imagine today, but there was a time when the average American feared for their safety and survival. In--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing lighting the city of Chicago is a half moo and burning buildings.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: --Chicago a coal strike, started by communists labor, shut off all the power. Riots followed. And on--  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PARADE OF VETERANS march down a street lined with citiz and boy scouts. SHOTS RING OUT from a rooftop. Onlookers scream and scatter. Bodies lie bleeding in the street.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Armistice Day in Centralia, Illinois, veterans, fresh back from War were murdered by radicals. The red revolution was on our soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Edgar, in a long coat, waits outside watching the f of the men who exit. He approaches one, posing as a fan.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Excuse, me sir? (the man ignores him) Is Mrs. Goldman really in there?

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT JAIL
dialogues.text: Who's asking?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m a fan. I’ve read your writing as well. Do you work with her?

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT JAIL
dialogues.text: If you’re truly interested in the Party, then you shouldn’t be stalking members on the streets like a sycophant. Come to a rally. Organize.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But for now, may I have your autograph? Hoover holds out a newspaper with a story by the man, “Bolshevik America.” The man autographs the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar is with his new inner circle, THREE HANDSOME AGENTS Helen Gandy. WORKMEN are installing rows of filing cabine

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We can’t take them down one by one or they’1ll go underground and we’1l find a bomb in every Senator's (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: mailbox. It must be a simultaneous raid. Hitting all of them at once. An older agent with a BIG MUSTACHE has questions.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: And who are “they?”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s what you have to find out. We need a card on every radical person in the country. Who they are, where they live, what they say, what group they belong to.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: Who have already committed crimes?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I care less if they’ve already committed a crime, and more if they plan to.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT 2
dialogues.text: How many are on our team?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Only you four.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: I’ll have locks installed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No locks. That would draw attention. Nothing will be alphabetically ordered. The cards will be broken down into subjects and categories. The system will be simple enough if it’s been explained. If not, finding information will prove impossible. Trust no one. Not even fellow agents. Half of our colleagues are on both sides of the payroll.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: And the crimes we are investigating aren’t crimes... they are ideas?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: If their idea is to come to this country and plot the overthrow of our government, then that IS a crime.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Goldman is not an alien. She married a U.S. Citizen. Edgar opens the article he had autographed outside Prison

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The man she married hasn’t visited her once in prison, but the man she’s lived with since her wedding day... visits her nightly.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: Smells like a Mitchell Palmer publicity stunt to me. Tell me, John, what happens when we raid this list of yours, and we find NOTHING? No guns, no bombs, just innocent people deported--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (taking it personally) From every corner of this nation, the American people have urged the Attorney General to do something about the violence and return the United States to peace and glory. I am happy to send your objections to Palmer himself, but in the meantime, you will expose Miss Goldman’s sham marriage... and change that suit of yours.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT 1
dialogues.text: Pardon me, John?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (re: his unfashionable suit) Your suit. Have some respect for yourself, and more importantly show some respect to this Bureau. Edgar leaves the room in a huff. The other agents turn aw from the challenging mustached Agent. He’s played his han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar walks toward a group of press. Writers, Cameras, al waiting for him. They eye him curiously, who is this kid?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Today... um upon her release, Miss Goldman was immediately served (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: deportation papers... According to our information, she is one of the most dangerous anarchists in this county.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who are you, mister?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: John. John E. Hoover. It’s not a home run, but they scribble down his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An INSPECTOR oversees a formal examination. Edgar hands h checklist of accusations and sits directly in front of a tired looking Emma Goldman at a table filled with governm lawyers. He examines her ill fitting “fraud of a dress.” catches him doing it and is distracted.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: Miss Goldman, do you live with the Man you claim to be married to?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I decline to answer.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: Are you aware the man who married you had no authority to do so?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I decline to answer.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: Miss Goldman, are you an anarchist?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I decline to answer

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: (growing frustrated) Do you deny that you are an anarchist?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I decline to answer.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: Do you believe in the overthrow by force or violence of the Government of the United States?  20.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I refuse to answer.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: Do you advocate the assassination of public officials?!

dialogues.speaker: EMMA GOLDMAN
dialogues.text: I refuse to answer.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR SCHELL
dialogues.text: (composes himself, then) This ALIEN has refused to answer any questions pertaining to the charges contained in the warrant, notwithstanding the fact that every opportunity was afforded her... I recommend deportation. EDGAR’S POV: of old Caminette’s face (earlier). Again, TH

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And just like that, we had our precedent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The File room has grown exponentially. The cabinets are spilling over. Edgar is pulling out cards. There are LIGH STRING CONNECTIONS everywhere. Helen Gandy interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Edgar? Should I arrange our travel to Paterson for Valentines Day? There’s trepidation in his pause. Is this a romantic gest

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes... Of course, Miss Gandy.

SET TO: BOBBY BENTON’S 1963 hit “ROSES ARE RED (MY LOVE)” title card reads: VALENTINES DAY, 1920. An Army of 500 Police, 35 troopers and bomb squad detecti barge out of a station and fan out across Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI MEN in white shirts, ties, and winter coats and POLIC with copper badges and batons burst into a building. They  21. greeted with jeers, taunts and bottles from the Russians anarchists inside. The batons come out. Heads are split. Students are pushed down stairs, bookcases are overturned, there’s blood and broken bones everywhere -- IT’S VIOLENT AND BLOODY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A puff of smoke as Edgar lights up a cigarette try and calm his nerves. Helen Gandy is sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: They found a counterfeiting press, five pistols, two automatics. And in Trenton, they found gunpowder, copper, brass wire, batteries--

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: A bomb factory.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: 120 arrests in Detroit, 41 in Philadelphia, 17 here, so far. REVEAL: On his lap are 33 more warrants “for subversive radical activity.” Can’t leave the work at the office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black sedans drive slowly down the snow covered street. T lights shut off and they coast to a stop. Edgar and Helen feet step out quietly. But this is no date -- a dozen oth officers get out with them. A SECRET SERVICE OFFICER preps his ten men.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: These men are armed, violent, and prepared to kill to avoid capture-- Privately, Edgar hands out firearms to SIX OF HIS MEN.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: Are we allowed to use these, sir?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: These are gifts from me to you. There is no law preventing us from using our own weapons. Edgar can’t naturally handle a firearm. He tucks it away, concealing it from a journalist and Miss Gandy who stand remove.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bureau Agents, Secret Service, and local cops burst throu the front door, guns drawn. It’s a classic raid.

dialogues.speaker: CHORUS OF OFFICERS
dialogues.text: Hands in the air. -- On the ground. THE RADICALS inside dive for cover, reach for weapons or up stairs, but they are quickly tackled, beaten, and purs One YOUNG RADICAL escapes up the stairs. Two agents chase him. Edgar, the last in the door, slowly starts up the st after them. HE CAN HEAR A SCUFFLE. It sounds violent. He slows his step, and draws his gun. He reaches the door, ready to fire the first shot of his life, but finds it’s not a scuffle at all. The young radi is being beaten within an inch of his life by the officer Edgar watches. He’s never seen such violence first hand. it revolting? Titillating? Both?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s enough. The room goes silent, making the screaming downstairs see all the louder. Edgar ignores it. He’s focused on: A PRIN PRESS in the corner -- AND A STACK OF PINK PAPER -- ident to the color found the night of the Palmer house bombing. STRING LIGHT FLASHES OUT THE WINDOW AND CONNECTS TO -— EXT. ATTORNEY GENERAL PALMER’S HOME —- FLASHBACK --all of the PINK PAPER at Palmer’s house months ago. Edgar has completed the circle -- Guns, bombs, and the solution to the Palmer raid mystery. The raids are a succ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow covers the ground. Edgar is dressed warmly, walking a congressman, dignitaries and reporters. Hundreds of prisoners are being marched through the snow, single file to a gangplank and onto a tugboat. Edgar watc a tired, filthy Emma Goldman struggle up the gangplank to tugboat and disappear. The camera reveals a massive, rotting 5000 ton ship, THE BUFORD. This won’t be a pleasant journey for the prisoner Above them all looms the mighty Statue of Liberty.  23.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But everyone in the Bureau involved in those arrests lost their jobs, correct? Even Palmer himself?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Most did. And there is the lesson. The bombs stopped. Peace came. And the American people forgot there was ever a threat. -- EXT. ATTORNEY GENERAL PALMER’S OFFICE - 1921 From afar, Edgar watches assistants carry boxes out of hi boss’s office as Palmer takes a moment to assess his loss

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: -- So when political adversaries attacked Palmer in his run for the White House, when they attacked the Bureau, the country let it happen. Palmer feels eyes on him, and looks up to Edgar. INT. HOOVER’S INNNER OFFICE - DAY - 1964

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FBI MAN
dialogues.text: But why Palmer and not you? If you orchestrated the raids...

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (defensive, a sore spot) I was only twenty four years old. I was following orders, Agent Smith.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FBI MAN
dialogues.text: (regretting the question) I understand, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: But If we hadn’t of done it, you may very well have been born into a communist State instead of the country you love today, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG FBI MAN
dialogues.text: Of course, sir. A door opens across the hall. Hoover looks up and sees th earlier silhouette again limping toward his glass back do OLD MAN’S VOICE Edgar?  24.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (quietly to Agent Smith) Ignore him. OLD MAN’S VOICE Edgar!

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Toulson! I will be out ina moment. I am in a meeting. OLD MAN’S VOICE Don’t forget your appointment with the Attorney General, Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The file is not complete yet, Mr. Toulson. Go away! The casual familiarity of the exchange in front of Agent Smith bothers Hoover. Smith is packing up. Hoover extends his hand for a shake, apparently wanting to dispense with the earlier tension.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SMITH
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. I apologize. I will finish this chapter tonight.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Very good, Agent Smith. The Agent goes. Hoover checks the hand he just shook with The young agent’s palm was sweaty. He seems heartbroken. had truly liked Agent Smith-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Hoover is in his outer office with a new agent, AGENT JON 22. He’s from Indiana. He’s by the books.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Say I wanted to include the story of how I became director. Do they tell that story in the Academy?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Yes sir... You were called into the new Attorney General’s office--

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Harlan Fiske Stone.  25.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Attorney General Stone. He called you into his office and told you to sit down, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Edgar is let into HARLAN FISKE STONE’s office. Ston 60, an imposing figure at 6’6” and 260 lbs.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: Sit down. Edgar does. Stone examines him intently over his desk. Ed calms his nerves by manically talking business.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Sir, there are almost a dozen vacancies in Chicago. With the robbery rate rising it would actually profit the bureau to fill these vacancies and start making recoveries. I have cabinets filled with files on suspects, and with a Congressional hearing--

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: Lower the treble, son. You didn’t call this meeting. I did.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: Everyone you’ve worked with here is gone. And there’s a reason for that. This Bureau is of exceedingly bad odor. Would you agree?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: And no offense, but you seem to have no social life, no wife, no girlfriend, and as far as I can tell, no pals... at all.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s accurate, sir.  26.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: And you’re shamelessly distracted by this hodgepodge fingerprinting affair.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t be a hodgepodge if we could centralize the prints here.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: It’s a speculative science at best.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: And why do they call you “Speed?”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Who calls me that?

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: They all do... Behind your back evidently.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (unaware, covering) Well... S- S- Sir, I earned a reputation for delivering groceries when I was ten years old. I was the fastest in the neighborhood. It was a nickname.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s not for the way you talk?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Perhaps, sir. A long beat of silence. Edgar is ready and willing to be fired -- if only to stop the humiliation. Instead:

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: Young man, I want you to be acting director of the Bureau of Investigation. Edgar absorbs the unexpected good news, covers his shock, looks back across the desk at Stone’s imposing forehead.  27.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’1l take the job, Mr. Stone... But only on certain conditions. Stone gives a quizzical look. How dare he name conditions

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (as if prepared) The Bureau must be divorced from politics, and not be a catch-all for political hacks. Recruits must be college educated. Appointments must be based on merit. Promotions will be made only on proven ability... And the bureau will be responsible only to you sir, the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: HARLAN FISKE STONE
dialogues.text: (a beat, then) I wouldn’t give you the job under any other conditions... (cutting Edgar off) That’s all. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the agents in the FBI are lined up in two long, ne ending rows, facing each other. Edgar walks down the long isle between them, shaking each Agent’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I am determined to summarily dismiss from this Bureau any employee whom I find indulging in the use of intoxicants. I-- He gets to a chubby agent, shakes his hand. Sweat. He tur to Helen beside him. She takes note. He continues, indica each man with a bald spot, each man not neatly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --believe that when a man becomes a part of this Bureau, he must so conduct himself, both officially and unofficially, as to eliminate the slightest possibility of criticism as to his conduct...  28. He stops at a handsome linebacker of an agent with dark h RAYMOND CAFFREY, 29. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) And your name, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND CAFFREY
dialogues.text: Agent Caffrey, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What is your assignment?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND CAFFREY
dialogues.text: Special Agent to Kansas City, aiding in the search for escaped murdered Frank Nash, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s dangerous work. But when you return, you will be rewarded for you service to our country. Edgar shakes his hand. This is the kind of Agent he wants his Bureau (and his dinner table). Next to him though is MUSTACHED AGENT who challenged Edgar during the Palmer ra YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) You still fancy facial hair, Agent Stokes?

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: The ladies appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: And the ladies’ opinions’ are more important than the Bureau’s?

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: No... sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Stokes, perhaps you are better suited for the Police force than the Bureau of Investigations.

dialogues.speaker: MUSTACHED AGENT
dialogues.text: I’ve been here seven years, Edgar. As long as you.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. You were with the old bureau seven years. That bureau is gone.  29. INT. BASEMENT BED - (HOOVER’S MIND?) Edgar stands above his emaciated father, examining him wi scientific curiosity. The man’s eyes open wide, lock on h son and he lets out a TERRIFYING SCREAM. Edgar bears it. Silence. His father dies, his jaw still ajar, mid scream. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME / HOOVER’S BEDROOM - DAY A WORKMAN is installing a personal telephone line into Edgar’s childhood (and current) bedroom. Dressed all in black, Edgar supervises from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Why the phone in your son’s room and not in the master bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m paying you to put in a line, not ask questions. And Edgar pulls out a pack of LUCKY STRIKES. EXT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME / FRONT PORCH - MOMENTS LATE Edgar and his NEICE, 12 (also in black), are smoking.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG NEICE
dialogues.text: I thought Lucky Strikes were only for girls.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You thought wrong. Hold it in your lungs or it’ll do you no good. Bouncing up the street in a bonnet holding a mass of shop bags (and not in black at all) is Edgar’s mother. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME / KITCHEN - THAT NIGHT Edgar’s mother spins around in a new dress.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I had two made. Same cut, different pattern. And two suits for you. They'll be delivered on Friday. Edgar sits down at the dinner table. At his place is a sapphire ring. He examines it. She cozies up.  30. EDGAR’S MOTHER It’s platinum. Six diamonds and a star sapphire. I’ve told everyone in the neighborhood. They all know.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What about the funeral for father? EDGAR’S MOTHER (serves up some pot roast) There’s no time for that now.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t mother. I’ve been gaining weight. EDGAR’S MOTHER It’s solid weight. There’s nothing wrong with solid weight on a man. I’m so incredibly proud of you, Edgar She pulls out a clipped newspaper article. It’s small, ba a mention, but it announces his new job. EDGAR’S MOTHER (CONT’D) I’m starting an album for you. I’m going to put everything in it. This is just the beginning. He slips the sapphire ring on his finger -- where it will remain the rest of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar holds court at his corner table with SPECIAL AGENT CHARLES APPEL and another handsome agent. The wait staff them special attention, but Edgar doesn’t notice. He has eye on a GROUP OF YOUNG MEN celebrating at the bar. Edgar is focused on a tall, slender, SHARPLY DRESSED MAN. Trouble is, another man in the group, LAWRENCE RICHEY, kn Edgar, and waves. Edgar returns the gesture, but feels caught. His discomfort doubles when Richey heads toward h THE SHARPLY DRESSED MAN JUST BEHIND (CLYDE TOULSON, 28).

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE RICHEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover! Good to see you. I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Clyde Toulson. He graduated from George Washington University Tonight. With a law degree.  31.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Toulson.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (the quiet type) Thank you. I believe you’re one of our most distinguished Alumni.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I did... yes... I do... have a degree from the school. Yes. (an awkward beat; covering) I was just admiring your suit, Mr. Toulson. You could take a lesson from him, Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: It’s a custom cut. From Garfinkel’s Department store, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Do you have a card, Mr. Toulson?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I do. Of course. Clyde hands his card to Edgar. Edgar looks it over, hands Clyde his own card, and just as quickly goes back to his -- as if he never paid Clyde any special attention. YOUNG TOULSON (CONT’D) Thank you, sir. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Helen and Edgar are going through applications. One pile interviews, one for rejects. The reject pile is stacked h

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: (redacting an application) Well educated. Highly recommended. Willing to guarantee five years service... Has a family in New York... And a new baby.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No interview.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: The family in New York or the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years is not enough. We want men willing to dedicate their lives. How many is that so far?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: 320 denied, and 21 interviews.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Did you receive an application from a Mr. Toulson?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: (finds the report, wary) Yes... His report states he, “has confidence, poise, his diction is excellent.” But, “Although physically fitted for it, might be displeased with rugged work.” His only interest in the Bureau is to gain experience that would benefit a private law practice. And he has no interest in being here for any period of time, which would, “Render employment speculative.” She waits for him to say “No interview,” but he doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He did receive a letter of recommendation from the executive assistant of the Secretary of War.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s fantastic, Miss Gandy.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: He, well... mentions here that Mr. Toulson, “Showed no particular interest in women.” It’s 1930’s code for gay. She offers a bright side. HELEN GANDY (CONT’D) Then again, some of our best agents excel because they have... no family incumbrance.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You're right. Bring him in for an interview.  33. Helen adds him to the yes stack. Edgar tries to change th subject. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) The problem, Miss Gandy, is that these men don’t look up to me.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Of course they do.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I don’t mean figuratively. I mean. They don’t look UP to me. He doesn’t want to be any clearer than that. It’s too sensitive a subject -- he’s shorter than most.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Well... if you could conduct the entire interview from behind your desk instead of walking about the office, I could correct that.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (considers it, then:) Miss Gandy, say I had private information on someone in a position of power. Harmful information... Now Destroying information goes against my nature, but I don’t trust it in the general files either. Could I trust it with you? If we created a confidential file?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Of course, Edgar. And with that, he slides his first “Private and Confident file across his desk to her. IT’S MARKED “ELEANOR ROOSEVE She sets it carefully in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD Miss Gandy sits outside the A.G.’s office with A STAC SIMILAR FILES IN HER LAP. She patronizes ROBERT KENNEDY'S SECRETARY with a smile.  34. INT. ATTORNEY GENERAL ROBERT KENNEDY’S OFFICE - SAME TIME Kennedy stands by a window, pensive. A FILE sits casually the corner of his desk. Hoover is relaxed in a chair, foc on a FIREPLACE in the office. He breaks the silence:

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Was the fireplace always here or did you have it put in?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: It was put in... What were you doing with wire-taps in that house?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: You asked that I pursue this “Organized Crime” element, Mr. Kennedy, and that’s what I did. With diligence... Do you use the fireplace?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Rarely... Who else has heard the recording?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’ve filed this matter “Personal and Confidential” I’m the only one with access to it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, I asked you to pursue a real threat. Instead you have publicly denied the existence of Organized Crime, and now this gross display of intimidation.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Sir, I was only following orders. We bugged the basement of a home in Los Angeles that is a known gathering place for lawbreakers. How was I to know that a criminal’s girlfriend and an east German communist would be down there having sex with your brother, the President of the United States. Do not shoot the messenger, sir. I am here to protect you both.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?  35.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: If this information was discovered by the public it would create wide spread distrust in your brother’s leadership ability, and before all else, I hold the well being of our Country paramount.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: So how may I HELP you, Mr. Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: If I am to pursue the elements you consider a threat, I humbly request that you allow me the same power and access to follow the groups I see as IMMEDIATE threats.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: It’s not 1920 anymore.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Do you know who Stanley Levinson is?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: A lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: A white communist lawyer who is organizing at the highest levels. Including the SCLC. His group is growing, their aim is entirely self serving, and their leadership is openly critical of this Department. Have you read the clippings I sent?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: I can’t say I have. Hoover pulls out the critical newspaper clippings (the on that made him sweat in the opening scene).

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: They claim we are, “Unable to get convictions in even the most heinous crimes,” and that we have, “Faltered under the pressure, complexities and responsibilities of our office.” In PRINT in the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You can’t bear a little criticism?  36.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: It depends on what their aim is... They are gaining considerable power, their priorities are singularly focused on their own issues, and they are trying to incite revolt.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Frankly, they sounds more critical of your office than mine... There’s a new face to communism, Edgar, and this isn’t it. Communism is a foreign threat now. Not domestic.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Kennedy. Before you were even born, I heard that very same argument from a Mr. Mitchell Palmer. And do you know what it took to change his mind? A bomb. If he had sat in his smoking chair five more minutes that night in 1919, we would have been lucky to have found an intact index finger. I do not want to see that happen to you, or your brother. (attempting a conciliatory tone) There’s no reason we can’t both get what we want. We can wage a war on two fronts, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: You can go now. And please leave the transcripts with me.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Feel free to share them with your brother. I have a copy of my own, in safe keeping. And with that threat, Hoover walks toward the door, stops the fireplace, inspects it, and goes, a smile creeping in the corners of his mouth. The rhythm of his shoes on the flooring cross the cut, matching the rhythm of-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1924 --Young Edgar doing push ups in his office with the windo open to let in air and dry his brow. FOOTSTEPS! Edgar takes a handkerchief from his pocket and dabs his b but he’s not sweating.  37.

dialogues.speaker: MISS GANDY
dialogues.text: Your four o’clock is here, sir. He hurries to close the window, but the curtain gets stuc the window jams, and the handkerchief falls from his pock He heads for his desk. His office door opens. Miss Gandy in the next applicant, it’s dapper Clyde Toulson (earlier

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Mr. Toulson. Edgar rounds his desk and STEPS UP ONTO A NEW SMALL PLATF TO MAKE HIM TALLER. Clyde smiles, trying to relieve Edgar embarrassment. He steps toward the desk and extends a han

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, thank you for this opportunity. A SIDE SHOT reveals Edgar standing on his riser, still no quite as tall as Clyde. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Please. Take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: There are several problems with your application, Mr. Toulson, not the least of which is you do not show the required dedication to the bureau, nor the dedication t-- As Edgar rattles, he watches Clyde’s eyes. Clyde sees the curtain stuck in the window. He sees the handkerchief on floor, and the spot of sweat forming on Edgar’s brow.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --t--t--to... th-- (speeds up to stop stuttering) the protection of the American people and the American way. This is NO platform to a fatter paycheck in private practice. We see what Edgar sees: LIGHT STRINGS connect the evidenc Clyde is looking at. It seems to Edgar that Clyde can see strings as well. It’s frightening, invasive, titillating  38. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) Is there something the matter, Mr. Toulson?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Is exercise a requirement for all Agent’s, Mr. Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (busted? ) All agents must be in excellent physical condition. We must out Match and out wit the public enemy at every turn.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: What kind of routine do you do?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (making it up) sit ups... push ups... squatting...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: How about chin ups?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I see. Would you like me to fix the curtain, Mr. Hoover? Or perhaps open the window? I always enjoy the air after exercise. Don’t you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: If it would please you. And Clyde carefully and expertly removes the curtain from window, bends over, plucks up the handkerchief off the fl and returns it to Edgar's desk.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Where I may fall short in terms of resume, I apparently far exceed the rest in terms of honesty. I did not lie to get this interview. Like the rest, I WOULD like to start a private practice eventually, but I could be persuaded otherwise if the right opportunity arose.  39. EXT. GARFINKEL’S DEPARTMENT STORE - DAY Edgar steps out of a limousine and walks into the departm store. Clyde gets out behind him and follows him in. INT. GARFINKEL’S DEPARTMENT STORE / MONTAGE - DAY Edgar is measured for a suit -- Clyde supervises fabric choices -- Clyde pulls out ties and shoes -- Edgar tries 3-PIECE-SUIT. It’s the first time we’ve seen him this put together. He looks like the “Hoover” the world now knows. INT. GARFINKEL’S DEPARTMENT STORE - LATER Edgar is with a clerk, his items laid out on a counter. C is at a remove. Something’s wrong. Things get uncomfortab when the department store CREDIT DIRECTOR appears.

dialogues.speaker: CREDIT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Are you Mr. John Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I am. Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: CREDIT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: It seems there’s a Mr. John Hoover whose credit has gone bad with us. That would appear to be you.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (quiet, humiliated) That’s not me. On my word. My parents call me Edgar, my niece calls me J.E. And I sign John E, not John.

dialogues.speaker: CREDIT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Sir, may I suggest you choose ONE name, and re-apply. He presents a new application. Edgar looks at the blank N SPACE. He puts a pen to the page, and writes. “J. -- EDGA HOOVER.” The camera focuses in on the soon to be famous n INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE — DAY Edgar walks in wearing his new 3-piece-suit with a pocket square -- the more dapper look he’1ll carry the rest of h life. Helen Gandy greets him with a grim face.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You don’t like it?  40.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover. There’s been a massacre in Kansas City.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: One of ours?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (his worst fear) Special Agent Caffrey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUN FIRE AND SMOKE. Cars screech to a halt. Passengers ru for their lives. Police officers scramble for cover.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Let ‘em have it! A MAN WITH A MACHINE GUN beside a Plymouth starts firing two officers. Another gangster behind a second car opens fire. The two cops immediately fall to the ground, dead. A MAN catches a bullet in his arm. He drops to the ground scrambles to the side of a Chevy, TOWARD AGENT CAFFREY(Th dark haired linebacker of an agent Edgar complimented earlier). Caffrey scrambles to the driver’s side of his Chevrolet t provide safe haven for the wounded man, but he’s cut shor A BULLET BLASTS THROUGH HIS HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By 1930, The communist threat had been beaten back, but-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - 1930 - DAY A MOVIE CREW has lit Edgar’s office. Clyde is by a window dressed as an FBI Agent. It’s sexy on him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --the depression had hit, and their was a new threat. The bank robber, the car thief and the kidnapper. But like communism, America didn’t react with scorn, they gave the American gangster their admiration.  4l. Edgar is in his new suit behind his desk. Two flags flank making the perfect stage. A makeup woman powders his nose

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Whenever you’re ready, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Our nation is under attack from within. The problem of organized gang warfare and the defiance by desperate armed criminals of the forces of society and civilization can no longer be ignored.--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Audience watches the newsreel featuring Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: --Pretty Boy Floyd is now Public Enemy Number one. Look around you. He could be anywhere. With your help, the American gangster’s days are numbered. The Audience is none too pleased with Edgar’s announcemen Boos, popcorn at the screen. The projectionist cuts it sh A trailer fades in. It’s PUBLIC ENEMY starring JAMES CAGN as the dashing gangster. THE AUDIENCE ERUPTS WITH APPLAUS INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Old Hoover is again talking to Agent Jones -- who is more focused on the WORKMEN DEMOLISHING HOOVER’S BACK WALL.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: But that summer, a single crime opened the door to set things right. Do you know what that was, Mr. Jones?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: (distracted) I’m sorry, sir, what was that?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Who is the most famous man of the 20th Century... thus far?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Joe McCarthy, sir?  42. Hoover clearly disapproves. This guy is toast. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Old Hoover has a new, VERY SWEATY AGENT, at the typewrite

dialogues.speaker: SWEATY BALDING AGENT
dialogues.text: The most famous? Is that you, sir? Hoover is focused on the bald spot forming on the crown o the Agent’s head. That and the sweat are deal breakers. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Hoover is with yet another Agent, AGENT GARRISON. This on very young and handsome with a North Carolina accent.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT GARRISON
dialogues.text: Well I suppose his notoriety depends on the field he is in.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: His field... was in the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT GARRISON
dialogues.text: Then Charles Lindbergh, sir. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME / HOOVER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - The private phone (earlier) rings. It’s 11PM. Edgar is in childhood bed, asleep. He stirs and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes?... Send officers from Trenton. I will be on the first train. His mother comes in. He hangs up. He looks truly disturbe EDGAR’S MOTHER What is it?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The Lindbergh’s baby has been kidnapped. EDGAR’S MOTHER (deeply shocked) You have to find him, Edgar. He has to be brought home alive.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, mother.  43. EXT. THE LINBERG’S HOME / NEW JERSEY - DAYBREAK Edgar and Clyde arrive at the Lindbergh home, a big white house in the middle of a field. All around are POLICE CAR and GIANT LAMPS that must have burnt all night. Like the Palmer crime scene, Edgar looks for clues, littl LIGHT STRINGS making connections. AN OFFICER talks AT Cly

dialogues.speaker: NJ OFFICER
dialogues.text: This morning alone we’ve heard from the Pennsylvania railroad, Will Rogers, President Hoover, Governor Roosevelt, the Customs Department, the U.S. Mail and the Boy Scouts-- EDGAR WATCHES THE NJ POLICE trudge around an area under a opened upstairs window. He shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: All of you. Get off of that dirt. You are trampling evidence. Colonel Shwartzkoff (clearly the one in charge) approache

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: There’s nothing there. No defined footprints. It seems he was wearing fabric on his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: And you don’t think the size of the print may have held some value? (re: the upstairs window) And how did he get up there? Are there marks on the window and wall you're erasing as well?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: There was a ladder. We found it a hundred yards away in three pieces. We moved it inside.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You moved it?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: Yes. For safe keeping.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You’ve completely contaminated the crime scene. Now (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: if you please, get your boots off of this property, Mr. Shwartzkoff.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: What right do you have to be here, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: J. Edgar Hoover. Director of the FBI. We have been sent by President Hoover himself to make sure this crime is resolved successfully.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The President has authorized access to all documents and evidence--

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, you are free to observe, but New Jersey is not the President’s domain.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where is Mr. Lindbergh? I’d like to hear his opinion on the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by workmen installing a bank of phone lines, E hovers over THE LADDER: it’s home-made, each of it’s thre pieces measure 80.5 inches. We see Edgar’s LIT STRINGS as makes connections -- the sections must have fit neatly in each other to form a 20 foot ladder that would collapse t A side-rail on the center section has split along the gra

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: He fell five feet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: Who did? Reveal CHARLES LINDBERGH, dressed well, but bearing the s of no sleep. He seems interested in what Edgar has to say

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The kidnapper... with the child in his arms, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: That’s speculation, Mr. Hoover.  45.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Lindbergh, sir, if it had split on the way up, it would have collapsed. It was a miscalculation. Built to bear the weight of a man going up, but not the weight of a man and a child coming down.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: We have other theories.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (annoyed, but careful in front of Lindbergh) And the ransom note? May I see the note please, Mr. Shwartzkoff? Shwartzcoff pulls it out and hesitantly offers it up. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) You’ve been touching it with your bare hands as well?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: We checked. There were none of the “finger imprints” you fancy so valuable, Mr. Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: None YOU could find perhaps. Would you please put it down? A moment of eye contact between Edgar and Lindbergh, then Edgar reads it, we see all the clues: the distinct spacin spelling and grammar GLOWING IN HOOVER’S TRADEMARK MANNER

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Have 50,00$ redy. we will inform you were to deliver the Mony. We warn you for making anyding public or for notify the police. Indication for all letters are SINGnature” S-I- N-G SING-nature “And 3 holes.” And the camera zeros in on the THREE HOLED SYMBOL the kidnapper made in the bottom corner of the letter.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want this letter. And the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF
dialogues.text: (leans in close) There is no Federal jurisdiction (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SHWARTKOFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: here. I’ve shown you what you asked for. It’s time for you to go. Edgar looks to Lindbergh who is examining the letter now. seems exhausted, helpless, unsure of who to trust. EXT. LINDBERGH’S HOME / HOOVER’S CAR - LATER Edgar and Clyde get back in their car.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m afraid for his boy.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: He trusts the local police more than us.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. He thinks we’re ALL fools. He’1ll go around them too. He’1l1 bargain with the kidnappers. INT. U.S. CONGRESS -— DAY Edgar sits with Clyde before a Senate Committee. He’s a brilliant speaker, never looking down, never pausing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: President Hoover called me the morning the child was taken and asked that I do whatever was in my power to help solve this crime. But do you know what ALL OF THE POWER OF THE FBI means without federal laws? Without arms? Without the power to make arrests? It means nothing. If we are one nation under God then we should have a force that can aid every state in this nation and stop the wave of crime that is pulling us into chaos. Mr. Chairman, I urge passage of the Lindbergh Law, making kidnapping a FEDERAL offense. To immediately deliver every finger print in the country to my office so that we may have a central file. To arm our agents so that we have a fighting chance against their sub-machine guns. I urge you to do this in the name of little Lindy. Because if he can be taken, then what child is safe? And if we cannot aid in his safe return, then what use are we?  47. It’s a smashing success of a speech. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Edgar watches from a window as trucks in the courtyard un massive files. Something weighs on him.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: What is it, Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The rest of the Fingerprints from Leavenworth and Chicago. She waits. He turns. That’s not what she meant. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) Our new President has scheduled a meeting... There’s talk of re- organizing the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: I’ve heard similar whispers.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Do you remember the file we built on his wife, Miss Gandy? Would you make a copy for me? He looks out the window and steps out onto the balcony. EXT. HOOVER’S BALCONY - CONTINUOUS Edgar puts on a big smile. Down below on Pennsylvania Ave is Roosevelt’s inaugural parade. Edgar WAVES DOWN to Roosevelt as his car passes, then heads back inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if a continuous (but 32 years later) Hoover comes in o the balcony. He is greeted by his young writer. Two worke at the far end are now building the FACADE OF A NEW FIREPLACE. It looks identical to Kennedy's.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Lindbergh hired criminals to look for his son. He even got an offer from Al Capone to help pay the ransom. And he employed an eccentric by the name of John Condon who'd placed a newspaper ad to act as a go- between between with the kidnappers.  48.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT GARRISON
dialogues.text: Was Condon a criminal too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white haired JOHN CONDON is escorted in and up to Lindy crib. It hasn’t been disturbed since the kidnapping night Pins still hold the covers down. The window is still ajar Mr. Lindbergh walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: Mr. Condon? You say the kidnappers responded to your ads?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: (hands over two letters) Twice now. I will reply in the newspaper if you’ll allow it... Did he leave the note in the crib?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: No. On the window sill. Condon looks at the pins securing the blankets in the cri

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: These pins are unique.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: My wife uses them to hold the covers in place. Our son had a cold when he was taken.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: Can I take them with me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: (not sure of this man) Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: So a mother may have her child again and that you may know that the American people are grateful for the honor bestowed upon them by your pluck and daring.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: How do we know these letters of yours are from the kidnapper?  49.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: The symbol matches the original letter’s symbol... doesn’t it? (silence) What is it Mr. Lindbergh?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: In a moment of thoughtlessness, I showed the symbol to some other men who had offered to help. I’m not sure they were trustworthy. I’m not sure anyone is trustworthy anymore, Mr. Condon. You should know that I have decided to have your letters analyzed to see if they are truly from the same author.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar storms into a law book jammed room with a studious looking man, MR. ALBERT S. OSBORNE, and several agents.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Clear all of these tables.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: Where do we put the books, sir?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Out of my sight... Mr. Osborne, what do you need from us?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT S. OSBORNE
dialogues.text: Bright lights. A microscope. Measuring instruments. Magnifying glasses... a projector.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You have the full resources of the Bureau. Don’t be shy, a child’s life depends on this.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT S. OSBORNE
dialogues.text: Okay. Paper samples... from every regional manufacturer.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Toulson, you will get Mr. Osborne whatever he needs to conclude without a doubt that these letters come from the same author.  50. And with that, Edgar puts the three Lindbergh notes on th now book cleared table. Lindbergh has handed them over. EXT. THE ATTORNEY GENERAL’S PRIVATE LIBRARY - LATER Clyde stands with an impatient Edgar, outside the makeshi lab. A SIGN indicates this is the Attorney General’s libr

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Should we tell the Attorney General?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: So he can say “no” for the third time? Just post a sign.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: To say what... “Keep out?”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. “FBI Crime Laboratory.” Have it carved in wood and nailed in. If he wants it gone, he can pull it out himself. It’s time we have at least one thing the bad guys don’t.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Decorating skills?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Science, Clyde. Albert Osborne walks out of his lab. Edgar perks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT S. OSBORNE
dialogues.text: The ink is different, but the handwriting is a match. Whoever Mr. Condon is corresponding with IS the person who wrote the original note.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: OR... Condon wrote all the notes himself.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Lindbergh is planning to deliver the ransom money through Condon. It may have already happened.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Call the Internal Revenue Service. Get them to Lindbergh’s home. I insist those bills be marked.  Sl. Edgar starts down the hall. Albert stops him with:

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT S. OSBORNE
dialogues.text: Is that all, Mr. Hoover? I have a 2:30PM class to teach.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No you don’t. Consider your pay doubled. You work for your country now, Mr. Osborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condon waits at the FRONT GATE rereading his instructions A MAN approaches, but walks right by. Condon checks his watch: 9:15 PM. He considers, then starts to leave. As he does, he sees a WHITE HANDKERCHIEF being waved from insid the cemetary through the bars of the gate. Condon approaches. The man is in an overcoat with a fedor covering his eyes, the handkerchief now over his nose and mouth. Each time Condon nears, he darts behind a gravesto pulling Condon deeper and deeper into the graveyard. Fina the man shouts out in a German accent:

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: Have you gotted the money?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: I can’t bring the money until I’ve seen the baby. Both men hear FOOTSTEPS. The man jumps a fence and runs.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I promise you there are no police.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: (shouts back as he runs) It’s too dangerous. The footsteps turn out to be those of a NIGHT GUARD. Cond waits for him to pass, then pursues the man deep into the park. Out of breath, and ready to collapse, Condon slows pace. So does the man with the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: No one will hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: If they catch me they will.  He slowly 52.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: They only want the child.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: They’1l give me thirty years if I’m caught. They could burn me.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: I didn’t do it. I am only the messenger. approaches Condon. Condon braces himself. MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD (CONT’D) What if the baby is dead? Would I burn if the baby is dead?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: Why would we be meeting if the baby was dead?

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
