dialogues.text: He’s not. He’s treated well. Better than the diet in the newspaper ad his mother put down. But would I burn if I did not kill it?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: No... And you’ve seen the child?

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: You gotted my letter with the sINGnature. It is the same like the letter with the SINGnature which was left in the baby’s crib.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: In the crib?

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: Yes. Condon was told differently. He pulls the pins from the baby’s crib from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: Do you recognize these?

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: Those are from the baby’s crib.  53.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: So you were there. Yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD
dialogues.text: (feeling busted, he flees) Place another ad in the paper when you have the money. And with that, the man vanishes. INT. LINDBERGH’S HOME / GARAGE - NIGHT Condon and Lindbergh are with an officious little IRS man ELMER IREY. Edgar, Clyde and AGENT SISK, watch him record numbers off each gold markered bill onto a ledger.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: I thought gold notes were going out of circulation, Mr. Irey.

dialogues.speaker: ELMER IREY
dialogues.text: That’s our hope. It will make these bills more identifiable.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: I have no need to pursue the money, Mr. Hoover. I only want my son.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: This isn’t just for your Lindy, sir. I’ve already assigned a 26 man team, lead by Special Agent Sisk here to pursue the case. If we let these people go free, no child will be safe.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: If they find out you’re involved, I may never see my son again.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We won’t pursue a single lead until your child is in his mother’s arms. You have my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in the audience, Edgar watches a newsreel fire up It’s a plea for the safe return of “Little Lindy” featuri the happy, curly headed toddler at his parent’s estate. Edgar looks to his left, to his mother, a tear on her che  54. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT Edgar’s mother walks in, sits on the edge of Hoover’s bed and wakes him. Only half awake, he seems very boyish. EDGAR’S MOTHER I had a nightmare, Edgar. That you were covered in blood. That you had split your skull open, and were left to die under a tree. You were found by two farmers passing on the highway. What trouble are you in, Edgar? Tell me. EXT. NORTHERN TIP OF ST. RAYMOND’S CEMETARY - NIGHT Condon walks alone. The night is dark, and there is only occasional passerby. He’s been waiting for a while. Final

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE GRAVEYARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ay, Doctor. REVEAL: This is Lindbergh’s POV from a Ford down the bloc He hears the voice. He watches Condon talk to the man fro afar, and then dissapear with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condon runs out of the cemetary, and up to the driver’s s door. Lindbergh doesn't see his child.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: I talked him out of 20,000 dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: I'd prefer him happy than save the Money, Mr. Condon. I don’t want to upset him.

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir. Lindbergh again sees the man with the handkerchief. This far in the distance. Lindbergh hands Condon the BOX OF MO LINDBERGH’S POV: Condon returns to the man, hands him the with his left hand and accepts an envelope with his right The man kneels down and inspects the money. Stands, shake Condon’s hand, blows his nose, drops the handkerchief and disappears. Condon makes it back to the car.  55.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: The baby? Where is the baby?

dialogues.speaker: CONDON
dialogues.text: (hands over the envelope) I promised to wait six hours before opening it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: Get in. Condon gets in. They drive away in silence. Charles resis opening the envelope, but he can’t. He tears it open.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gave your word. I did not. (reads the note) “The boy is on Boad Nelly. It is a small boad 28 feet long. Two person are on the boad. The are innosent. You will find the Boad between Horseneck Beach and Gay Head near Elizabeth Island.” EXT. THE SKIES ABOVE MARTHA’S VINYARD - MONTAGE - DAY Lindbergh flies his plane low, looking at every boat -- b the shore -- along the docks -- out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT GARRISON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What was in the boat?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: There was no boat. Lindbergh--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover is with his writer.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: --didn’t trust us. He wanted to do it his way. Who could blame him? Nobody respected us then. And at that moment, simultaneously, both the front and ba doors of this outer office open. From one end, Helen, fro the other, an bent over old man who was once handsome, th is OLD CLYDE TOULSON. Hoover only sees Helen.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, we’ve been calling--  56.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Edgar... Hoover turns toward the voice. He reads Toulson’s face.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Agent Garrison. It’s time to go. Garrison goes, but not before noting the familiarity betw Toulson and Hoover. Once alone with Toulson and Helen:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: The Attorney General has authorized your wire taps.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Very good, Miss Gandy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: (not so pleased) Are you sure you want this? Once you do it... it’s done.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: And when I prove myself correct, we will have saved this country another radical revolution. History will remember that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: And if you’re wrong, history will judge it an illegal move over a petty grudge.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (furious) Is our reputation petty to you, Mr. Toulson? Order the wires.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Can we discuss it over dinner?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: After you order the wires. He sees the tension in Hoover's face, the doubt. Helen go INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: (habitual, into her phone) The Director is on his way.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Agent sneaks in the service door of a hotel. EXT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER / INTERCUT Hoover and Toulson walk the hall to the elevator, side by side. Agents clear the halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agent picks the lock on a hotel room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching the elevators, Agents step out before their floo Hoover and Toulson step into an open, waiting lift. Their nightly departure is clearly choreographed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agent plants a microphone under a hotel room mattress

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover and Toulson ride down in silence together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An agent speaks into a microphone in a closet off the hal

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT AGENT
dialogues.text: J.E.H. approaching. And the pair step out of the elevator and into the hall - but it’s not Toulson and Hoover anymore, IT’S YOUNG, HAND CLYDE AND EDGAR -- WITH A FILE IN HAND. They sail toward the door. As they near it, an Agent open for them, not making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly timed, Edgar and Clyde walk out as an armored c pulls up, agents open the doors, and they load in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLACK DRIVER calls back.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Harvey’s Restaurant, sir?  58.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (we hear his nerves) No. To the White House. The car pulls out of the garage and into the atrium. Gian gates open letting them out onto Pennsylvania Ave. EXT. ROOSEVELT’S OFFICE - DAY Edgar sits outside Roosevelt’s office holding the file on lap, waiting patiently, watching the clock -- 5:30PM.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The President is ready for you, Mr. Hoover. And Edgar walks in, ready to fight for his job. INT. HARVEY’S RESTAURANT - THAT EVENING An old world, elegant restaurant. The staff is immaculate Edgar and Clyde are escorted to their corner booth withou word, complete familiarity. A few heads turn as they take their seats. It’s a corner table, a stage of sorts. INT. HARVEY’S RESTAURANT - LATER Edgar and Clyde have settled in to their booth.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s the same dance each time. They make me wait. They imagine I’m sweating, that they’re showing me who's boss. And I play along.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Did you play him the tape?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. The transcript. But he didn’t want to read it. That was unique. He wanted me to tell him about it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: How you came across it?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. I explained up front we had never expected to find Mrs. Roosevelt in the bedroom of a known communist agitator. Much less having what sounded like... an intimate moment. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (anxious laugh) And that I needed his guidance in how to proceed. I wanted him to know he had an ally.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Before he had a chance to ask you to resign.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Exactly, but when I was done, he simply pushed the file aside. He seemed unconcerned with it... Clyde, The President of the United States is afraid.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Afraid of you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Of a potential invasion from abroad. (to the passing Host) Sir, can we have a bottle of Dom?

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Of course, Mr. Hoover. Clyde gives Edgar a look. This is unusual.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: You're drinking now?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We're celebrating... I feel I can trust you with anything, Clyde--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I'd like to think so.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (a big secret) The President signed a secret order granting me increased power of surveillance. Secret surveillance of Communists and Radicals. Without warrant.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Is that legal?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Sometimes we have to break the rules if we are going to keep our country safe... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off Clyde’s concern) But to make sure I hadn’t heard wrong, I clarified it with Secretary of state Hull. He said, “Go ahead and investigate the cocksuckers.”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Vulgar.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Agreed. (searching Clyde’s eyes) I want to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Feel free.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I need someone who understands what’s at stake, who I can trust. An Associate Director of the FBI... I know you’ve only been with us 12 months...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: +--almost 18.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (strangely intimate) You're missing my point. Clyde, I want you to be my number two man.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I’m not one for the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I need you, Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (considers, then) Under one condition. (Edgar smiles) Good day or bad, if we agree or disagree, we never miss a lunch or dinner together.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’d have it no other way. The Host arrives with champagne, a reporter trailing him.  61.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, Mr. Walters from the Times is here to see you. The champagne pops. Edgar is as happy as he'll ever be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men drive along a small, muddy, isolated section of t road just near the summit, WILLIAM, 46, turns to the DRIV

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Only a half mile to Mt. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Can’t wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William wanders into the woods, ducks under a branch, unbuttons his coveralls, and looks down. What he sees is to believe -- sticking up through the dirt is what appear be a skull and a foot. The dirt all around is kicked up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Orville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orville perks up, gets out of the truck and wanders down. camera cranes up and over the trees, revealing not four m away, THE WHITE WALLS OF THE LINDBERGH’S HOME. EXT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT Edgar is at his mother’s bedside. She lies motionless in sipping medicine / sherry. Edgar is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The body was blackened, the left leg missing from the knee down. A visible fracture on the skull. He’d suffered a violent blow to the head... I told them months ago, he must have fallen on the way down, with the baby in his arms. She turns her head, clearly in pain. Clearly quite ill.  62. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) We are the sinners, we tolerated lawlessness in the land until it grew to diabolical proportions... The baby’s blood is on all of our hands. On your hands, Edgar. Edgar is horrified at the idea, but believes it deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS BEFORE: Edgar walks down the hall toward the press. Th time, when they see him and Clyde coming, they leap to attention, snap photos, and throw out questions.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: A short time ago, I spoke with the President. He ordered me to employ the full force of the FBI in solving this case. The day of the criminal in America is over. There will be justice before the year is out. That is a promise from the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: A CHORUS OF REPORTERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover! -- Mr. Hoover! Edgar loves the new attention. Clyde focuses in on a sing reporter who seems less than impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde has pulled the disinterested reporter aside for a private chat with Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How many more pieces can I run on Lindbergh’s employees and relatives? I need something fresh.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: And if the director gives you a piece of information, exclusively, how does the country benefit?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: The country? (reading Clyde) A story on the FBI? (reading Edgar) On its young director?  63.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What angle?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (considers, then: ) With the inescapable demise of the American Outlaw, the new American hero is the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: A story or a cover story?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: I can’t promise a cover. But I have a pal in the radio business if you’re willing to share true life stories. Maybe even a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (tamps down his joy) I would only want the truth to be told. Nothing colorful. Just who we are. Who I am. What we do. Toulson smiles at the reporter. They all know what Edgar really wants -- fame -- for himself and his FBI. INT. “G-MEN” COMIC BOOK / ANIMATION MONTAGE - DAY A CARTOON HOOVER is the star of the classic G-MEN comic. leaps to life through animation. Hoover totes a machine g

dialogues.speaker: FAKE HOOVER VOICE
dialogues.text: Give up Mr. X or it’s all over.

dialogues.speaker: CRIMINAL CARTOON VOICE
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: FAKE HOOVER VOICE
dialogues.text: The FBI. Then a flurry of machine gun fire makes the jump to: JUMP TO: COMIC BOOK HOOVER and a GAGGLE OF OTHER FBI AGEN raid a farm. As they bust down the door, a comic book lab the man in the door MACHINE GUN KELLY, with the bubble:

dialogues.speaker: MACHINE GUN KELLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot, G-men!  64. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT - 1933 Close on Edgar’s mother pasting another clipping in her n thick scrap book: “MACHINE GUN KELLY -- CAPTURED ALIVE.”

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Six weeks after the kidnapping, Congress passed the Lindbergh law making kidnapping a federal offense. The right to make arrests followed, then the right to bear arms. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Edgar slips a revolver into a holster under his vest. The handle has a mother-of-pearl grip.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I began collecting the finest scientific minds in the country. INT. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE / A.G.’S LIBRARY - DAY The three pieces of the LINDBERGH LADDER are carefully brought into the temporary lab in the A.G.’s old library. Edgar has his eye on the strangely dressed, introverted m who seems to be organizing things, ARTHUR KOEHLER.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: He claims to be the world expert on wood analysis.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s easy to be the expert if you're the only one in the world with any interest.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: He claims he can tell as much from a wood cut as a doctor can from an autopsy. He has some... social difficulties-—-

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Is he mentally ill?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Only as mad as you are... sir. The Attorney General storms across the hall toward Edgar.  65.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY GENERAL
dialogues.text: This was supposed to be a “temporary inconvenience”, Mr. Hoover. If you want your Sherlock Holmes playtime, I suggest--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where do you suggest I go?

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY GENERAL
dialogues.text: I suggest you take your case to congress and put my books back.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (turning red) Would you like me to tell the country we cannot solve the Lindbergh case because we can’t afford a proper labratory and the Attorney General won’t even let us use his library?

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY GENERAL
dialogues.text: Fine. Now Get your science fair project out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar sits before a packed hearing. Clyde sits beside him

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We must outsmart and outwit the foreign AND domestic criminal. THEY have chemists building bombs. We need chemists tracing their efforts. We must have the most advanced force in the world if we are to have the safest nation on earth.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: But Mr. Hoover, yours is already one of the most well funded departments in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That is true sir, but our car and bank robbery recoveries totaled 6.5 million last year, and our budget was only 2 million. Unlike other departments in Washington, we run a profit... And you cannot possibly quantify the value of our successes (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: with Pretty Boy Floyd, Baby Face Nelson, Machine Gun Kelly. SENATOR MCKELLER takes the mic. He’s not half as friendly

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, is it true that you directly or indirectly spend the Bureau’s money on advertising?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We are not permitted in any way to engage in advertising, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: But you take part, for instance, in the making of radio shows and comic books... I’ve seen several of these “G-men” programs, and your picture seems to be shown in conjunction with them quite frequently.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (very uncomfortable) We declined emphatically to lend any form of endorsement and had nothing to do with their production, furnished no advice, technical advice or other advice. Clyde leans back and tries not to look shocked -- this wa blatant lie. For the first time, Edgar starts to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: The very advertisement said the broadcasts were, “True reflection, as contained in the OFFICIAL RECORDS... Based on actual cases from the files of Federal Bureau of Investigation, Saturday nights at 8 o'clock.” (Edgar is speechless) Mr. Hoover, what are your exact qualifications for your leadership position with this Bureau?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (his job now at risk) 19 years with the Department of Justice. 12 as Director.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: And in that time, have you EVER Made an arrest, yourself?  67.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I have made investigations. I administer many cases at once, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: That’s not what I asked. The comics show you with a machine gun, making arrests. Is that just fiction?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I am responsible for thousands of arrests, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCKELLER
dialogues.text: So you admit it’s PURE fiction. In fact it wasn’t you who hunted and captured John Dilinger at all. It was Agent Purvis, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I have been in charge of all of these cases... but no sir, I have not personally made an arrest. Edgar’s blood is boiling, humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar marches out, rambling at Clyde at a frantic pace.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: We spend our lives working for justice, and the thanks we get is a political attack. Would they rather crimes go unsolved? Why is he fighting me? Start a file on Senator McKeller immediately. I want three agents on him at all times. Go through his trash. Photograph him at every dinner. Edgar arrives at his armored car and gets in. Clyde follo

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out. You can walk back.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: We have lunch. We don’t miss lunches. No matter what. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You pulled away from me in there.  68.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Edgar, but it was a lie. An easily provable one. If he had pursued it, there’s no telling how much worse it could have been.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (a beat, then) Find out where Agent Purvis is. He is to be demoted immediately, or better yet, fired.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Firing the man who killed Dilinger would be a PR disaster.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Then he’1ll spend the rest of his career behind a desk. And tell him if he wants to keep that job, he’d best keep out of the papers. Edgar shuts the door leaving Clyde on the sidewalk. The c drives off. The “lunch promise” is already broken, but it not the punishment Clyde took it as -- Edgar is breaking down. He sets in on a panic attack. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT Edgar sits next to his mother’s bed, soothing his woes wi bottle of Johnny Walker. She looks very sick.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know who to trust anymore, mother. Let me take you to a doctor. I can’t go on without you. Please, mother. We could go now. EDGAR’S MOTHER (barely a whisper) Faith, Edgar. Faith... Don’t wilt like a little flower. Be strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hum of the engines in mid air, Edgar, Clyde, and 12 AGENTS have chartered a plane. Edgar is manic.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The arrest is mine to make, understood? You will strictly follow Agent Toulson’s orders. (kissing up) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Agent Toulson is the finest agent in the Bureau today. His worth is second to none. In all of your careers, you can only dream of becoming half the agent he is now. Listen to his every word. The Agents nod out of duty. Toulson is uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is surrounded. Agents are poised on rooftops, stairways, and in cars all watching the apartment’s door. WE FOCUS ON: Edgar behind a car across the street, his gu his side. Clyde is a few cars up with his own. Out comes a WELL DRESSED WOMAN. She steps down to the cur lights a cigarette and looks around. The officers make themselves invisible, their fingers on their car keys and guns, ready for a signal. Edgar peaks up over his car as two men walk out of the building behind her, FRED HUNTER and ALVIN KARPIS. Edgar Karpis and toys with his trigger. As the trio starts towa car, the street fills with TRAFFIC AND PEDESTRIANS. The woman gets in the car first. The AGENTS wait for Edga make a move, but he’s focused on a MAN ON AN OLD WHITE HO sauntering into the lane beside the through traffic. Clip clop, clip-clop, slowly clip-clopping past. Fred is now i the driver seat, and Karpis is about to get in. Finally, the horse moves past Edgar’s line of vision. REV All three are in the car. Edgar throws a signal and all a once, the AGENTS descend with sawed off shotguns: Off roo down stairwells, their cars rushing in to block the stree Edgar rushes across the street from his hiding place, his heart pounding, Clyde a step behind. Karpis shuts his doo An Agent busts the driver's window with his shotgun, and points it at the driver’s head. Edgar arrives, flings open the back door, and aims his gu Karpis’s head. On the seat beside him is A RIFLE.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Put the handcuffs on him. AN AGENT pulls off his necktie, and ties Karpis’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Karpis. You are under arrest.  70.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A fast cut bust by “G-men” with guns of gangster William Mahan in bed in the middle of the night. Edgar is there t make the arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar leads Clyde and a team of Agents into an apartment building. He hands a Thompson machine gun to Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Blow it down. Clyde hesitates, then pulls the trigger turning the door swiss cheese. Bullets start flying back at them from behi the door. Edgar and the Agents duck for cover. Edgar’s Ag tear gas into the room. INT. APARTMENT BUILDING / JANITOR’S CLOSET - MOMENTS LATE Someone is firing from inside a closet. Agents stand on either side waiting for it to subside. When it does, they the door open revealing HARRY BURNETTE. He fires once mor but he’s out of bullets. Edgar steps into frame.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Burnette, you are under arrest. INT. HOOVER'S OUTER OFFICE -— DAY Edgar with a gaggle of reporters. They’re eating it up:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Karpis said he’d never be taken alive, but we took him without firing a shot. He shook all over -- his voice, his hands and his knees.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: And you arrested Harry Campbell in Toledo and Burnett in Manhattan as well, Mr. Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (false modesty) And William Mahan in California, but it was a WE job, not an I job.  71. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Clyde walks in holding a cereal box. Edgar takes it and d through it like a kid looking for the toy -- but without of the joy. Edgar pulls out a toy badge. It says “PURVIS. REVEAL: the front of the box has an image of Agent Melvin Purvis with: “THE FBI AGENT WHO CAUGHT DILINGER!”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Write the cereal maker. Let them know they must print any further boxes to read: “FORMER-AGENT” of the FBI. (with a grin) sit. I have something to show you. He pulls a letter from his desk, stifles a giggle, and re YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) “Only eight more days, funny how even the dearest face will fade away in time. Most clearly I remember your eyes with a kind of teasing smile in them, and the feeling of that soft spot just north-east of the corner of your mouth against my lips.” Edgar almost collapses with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s from Lorena Hickock, the White House reporter with the bad breath... to Mrs. Roosevelt!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Nothing. I accused her of having an affair with a man, but Old Horse Face is having an affair with Bat Breath! A woman! I was wrong! Helen Gandy sticks her head in. Edgar clears the tears fr his eyes. He can’t stop laughing.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover, they’d like to see you in the labratory.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’1ll be right there, Miss Gandy. (she goes) Clyde, the races begin in Del Mar next week. I was thinking of taking a quick vacation. I thought perhaps you’d like to join me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (smiles, considers) I’ve never been to a horse race.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful. And between you and me, when I lose my bets, the track covers the losses.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: And when you win?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: They pay!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: So where’s the thrill?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: In the sun that comes down in the stands. The hotel rooms. The service. The dinners. The company. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I would love to.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’ll have Miss Gandy make all the arrangements. It will be perfect!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Edgar... I’m afraid I can’t now. But perhaps in a few months... if I start saving.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. It’s covered. Completely.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I really couldn’t do that.  73.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You’ve done so much for me. For the Bureau. Consider it a thank you. (Clyde isn’t convinced) I’1l get a suite with adjoining rooms instead of separate rooms. That will be savings enough.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: It’s a deal. (smiles warmly) You should go. They’re waiting for you in the crime lab... Mr. Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly Edgar got what he wanted: The basement of the FBI been turned into a massive new crime lab. Rows and rows o files hold FINGER PRINTS. Rows and rows of SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS and LAB TECHNICIANS fill the halls. Edgar walks the long hall, finally arriving at an EXAMINA TABLE. Wood specialist, Koehler (earlier), has disassembl the Lindbergh ladder, each rail and rung numbered. As he explains his findings, we see Edgar’s LIGHT STRINGS connecting the evidence. These two are peas in a pod.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: There are several kinds of wood here. Pine. Birch. Fir. And if you look closely, you will see that each has its own internal markings, rings and knots, and its own external markings, as in here, from the machinery that milled the raw timber. And these, that mark the tools used to build the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (re: a long piece of wood) This one is very different.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: Yes. Number 16. It was a rail. And look at these four nail holes. They were NOT used in the construction of the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It was used for something else before the ladder was built.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: Yes. And it’s low grade sapwood with NO signs of weathering, so it was inside, not out. And the pine shows no signs of previous use. That tells us this ladder was built for THIS job. Nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: How does this help us identify the kidnapper?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: I need more money, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: For?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: Postage. I need to write to every mill on the East coast to see if their blades match these marks. Edgar considers. Is this guy for real, or really nuts? He looks at the wood again, and ALL THE CONNECTIONS LIGHT UP

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I want a report on each mill. And a map to track all leads. By the time I'm in New York, I want something to report, Mr. Koehler. INT. “G-MEN” MOVIE PREMIERE - NIGHT Up on the screen is the movie “G-Men.” Lighting quick Jam “Brick” Davis (JAMES CAGNEY) jumps through a window.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES CAGNEY, (IN THE FILM)
dialogues.text: Hold your fire! The machine guns go silent. He grabs the gun from the suspect’s hand and hip tosses him over a table to the flo Cagney now plays the “G-MAN” as the hero instead of “PUBL ENEMY NUMBER ONE.” The G-man has officially replaced the criminal as protagonist. The audience eats it up. REVEAL: Edgar next to Clyde watching with pride. EXT. “G-MEN” THEATER / RED CARPET - NIGHT On the RED CARPET afterward with Clyde and his mom, Edgar THE STAR. The press goes mad when A LITTLE GIRL WITH CURL Marches up and Edgar bends down to her.  75.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY TEMPLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover. I was wondering if you would join MY police force.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Why yes. If you agree to be an honorary G-woman, Miss Temple... and give me one little kiss.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY TEMPLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if your wife would approve, Mr. Hoover. The press laughs. So does Edgar. He shoots back:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: But Miss Temple, you see, I still live with my mother. The press eats it up. It’s everything Edgar ever dreamed for himself and his Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar gets in back with Clyde. His mother gets in the fro

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Are we going to the club?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (a finger to his lips) After we drop mother at the hotel. Clyde smiles. As the car pulls away, Edgar moves his hand top of Clyde’s like it’s the most natural thing in the wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar and Clyde are escorted in by the CLUB OWNER.

dialogues.speaker: STORK CLUB OWNER
dialogues.text: I have you at a table with Anita Colby. Lela Rogers and her daughter, Ginger, have asked if they can join.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: As long as it’s near the front. And he leads them through the oogling crowd in this, the exclusive night club in the city. It’s immaculate. The li music and decor make the Great Depression feel like ficti  76. INT. THE STORK CLUB / EDGAR’S TABLE UP FRONT - LATER Edgar holds court with a handful of actresses and singers amongst them: Lela Rogers and her daughter. He goes on at mile a minute, the women reacting with giggles and awe.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: The bullet entered the back of his head and exited through the front near his cheek. The thing people don’t realize is that there is very little blood. The heat of the bullet seals the wound as it enters. So the scene is far more peaceful than you depict in your moving pictures. REVEAL: Clyde is at a remove, literally pushed away by th women to listen from afar and deal with the WAITERS.

dialogues.speaker: LELA ROGERS
dialogues.text: And little Lindy? Did you see the child with your own eyes?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Those aren’t details I can share with a group of refined women. I couldn’t stand to make a single one of you shed a tear. But I assure you, we're on the case.

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: I saw the Lindberghs in Paris. I hardly recognized them.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Only justice can bring reason back to their lives... but I might share one confidential clue with you. If you will swear secrecy. He holds out his pinky. They giggle, hold out theirs and a four way pinky pact. More laughter. Lela doesn’t let go his pinky. She’s falling for him. He gets quiet:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The first gold notes from the ransom money have surfaced. And can you guess where?

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: Tell us... Please, Mr. Hoover.  77.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: In the Bronx. On three occasions. And each of the shop owners who turned them in claim they received them from a man with a pointed chin... and a German accent. Anita gasps and cozies up to Edgar. Lela clocks it. She w him to herself. Clyde watches it all play out from afar.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA COLBY
dialogues.text: (flirting) Take my word for it, Mr. Hoover, all the admiration in the world can’t fill the spot where love goes... or keep your bed warm. Clyde tunes in. Edgar tries not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I serve my country, Miss Colby. A nation’s admiration is more than enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA COLBY
dialogues.text: But it likely makes for a cold bed. The band strikes up “RED SAILS IN THE SUNSET.” Lela sees as an opportunity to pull “her Edgar” away.

dialogues.speaker: LELA ROGERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover. Would it be out of the question to bother you for a dance?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (suddenly panicked) How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LELA ROGERS
dialogues.text: Well... simply a dance. You do dance, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (turning red) It's a skill I haven’t mastered, and the night is getting long.

dialogues.speaker: LELA ROGERS
dialogues.text: Then no time like the present. This is my favorite song.  78.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (turning purple) Mr. Toulson, I think it’s t-t-time for us to go. We have a good deal of work t-t-tomorrow. I’m afraid I just don’t have t--t--time to dance. My sincere apology. N-- Now Mr. Toulson. This minute. And Edgar finally wiggles his way out of the table, clear running away from the women. Clyde follows. Lela and Ginger can’t contain their laughter. Edgar catch glimpse of it on his way out. He’s humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his mother’s bed is a now giant album of Edgar’s press clippings with a new shot of Edgar from the premiere’s pr book. Edgar is crying and stuttering at her beside.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I--I--I d--d--d-don’t like to d-d-- d--d-dance, a-a-- EDGAR’S MOTHER Edgar, go look in the mirror and talk the way the doctor taught you to. Be my little Speedie. He stands up, looks in the mirror, straightens his postur and starts talking in his fast, “speedie” way, the way th world knows him -- it’s his stutter cure.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, mother, I can spit my words out with precision, diction and clarity. I don’t like to dance. I don’t like to dance with anyone, but mostly I don’t like to dance with women, mother. It’s about time you knew. I find it humiliating and I refuse to be publicly humiliated. EDGAR’S MOTHER Edgar. Stop. (he does) Do you remember Barton Pincus?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (speedy in the mirror) His father was the watchmaker. He (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: was 10 years younger than me, and you called him “Birdie” or “Daffy.” EDGAR’S MOTHER Do you remember what happened to “Daffy” after the school custodian discovered him in the hoop skirt and the flower bonnet?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: He was made to stand outside our school wearing the skirt and bonnet as punishment. EDGAR’S MOTHER And did you ever wonder why we called him Daffy?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: For his odd behavior. EDGAR’S MOTHER It was short for daffodil, Edgar. And do you remember what happened to little Daffodile Pincus?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes... He shot himself six weeks after he stood outside school in that skirt. EDGAR’S MOTHER That’s right. And I thank God every day that my own sons don’t suffer from his condition. Edgar. I'd rather have a dead son than a daffodil for a son. She closes Edgar’s album and wills herself out of bed. EDGAR’S MOTHER (CONT'D) Now I’1l to teach you how to dance.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes mother. Edgar cannot even face her. He can only look at her throu the mirror. It’s a heartbreaking moment. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Lights, cameras, Edgar is filming a new televised speech.  80.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: It is imperative that we preserve and protect the morals of the American family. If the home is imperiled, if the home is destroyed, everything in our civilization crashes to its doom. Clyde watches from afar, surprised / concerned by Edgar's newfound passion for “traditional morality.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Koehler (wood expert) walks through the front gate the Millwork Company -- in the Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur compares samples of National Lumber’s wood to the on his evidence wood -- it’s an exact match.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: When did you get this shipment?

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: A long while back. November? 1931.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: Are you sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: MAN AT THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: It was either November or December.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: Three months before the kidnapping. The camera drifts outside and down the block to -- THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar, Clyde, Arthur and an army of other WELL DRESSED AG gather around a giant map of the northeast.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT ONE
dialogues.text: If the lumber yard is a cash business, then there aren’t any receipts or names.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: It tells us where he was shopping before anyone was looking for him.  81.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Read me the addresses where the ransom bills have turned up.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT TWO
dialogues.text: 456 west 3rd. (Edgar puts a pin in) 476 west 3rd. (another pin goes in) The sound goes out, but pins continue to go in. We focus Edgar watching -- making connections. The pins fan out fr single block, all centering around the lumber yard.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We knew who we were looking for. Someone who’d done business in this neighborhood for years. Someone who was still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The model G-Man, AGENT SISK questions a BANK MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I received, 2,980 dollars worth of these gold certificates. The customer signed his name J.J. Faulkner. Here is his address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Sisk flanked by Federal Agents burst into an apartm in the Bronx, guns drawn. It’s completely empty.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER BOY
dialogues.text: He was average height, blue eyes--

dialogues.speaker: BAKER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: High cheek bones and a pointy chin.

dialogues.speaker: THEATER CASHIER
dialogues.text: Yes sir, pointed chin, and an accent, an accent like--  82.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER BOY
dialogues.text: Like a German accent maybe.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAKER
dialogues.text: A German. With big cheek bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TELLER holds a $10 gold certificate:

dialogues.speaker: SCARED TELLER
dialogues.text: Am I going to get him in some kind of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SISK
dialogues.text: Not if he didn’t do anything wrong. We’re the FBI, son. The good guys.

dialogues.speaker: SCARED TELLER
dialogues.text: (considers, then) It was deposited by Walter Lyle. He manages the gas station. Up on Lexington and 127th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Sisk is with WALTER LYLE, he’s nervous, sweating as handles the gold note from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER LYLE
dialogues.text: Yes. I remember him. He bought 89 cents worth of gas.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: And paid with this bill?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER LYLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But I don’t know him. I’ve never seen him since.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: He was memorable enough that you’d remember it if he came in again?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER LYLE
dialogues.text: Yes. He was German, I think. I mean, with an accent. Pointed chin--  83.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT
dialogues.text: (withering; same old story) --and high cheek bones, right?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER LYLE
dialogues.text: Yes. And I guess I looked at the bill funny because he assured me he had 100 more just like it. At home.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SISK
dialogues.text: (perks up) You had a conversation with him?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER LYLE
dialogues.text: No. That was it. (Sisk withers again) But I wrote down his license plate number. That’s the writing right here along the edge of the bill. And he holds up the bill to show Agent Sisk -- BINGO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar walks the halls with purpose. Energized.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Miss Gandy, get Mr. Toulson. Helen emerges from her office and follows. Toulson does t same. They’re a trio by the time they burst through--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the investigating office doors. Agent Sisk is there, waiting at the pin covered map. He needs no prompting.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT SISK
dialogues.text: The New York Motor Vehicles Bureau’s describes it as a dark blue 1930 Dodge sedan. The owner is a carpenter who was born in Germany, and lives at 1279 East 222nd Street... in the Bronx. Sisk pushes a pin into the address. The map lights up in Edgar’s head. It all fits. The lumber yard, the cemetary, the spots the bills were spent. AGENT SISK (CONT’D) His name is Richard Bruno Hauptmann.  84. EXT. ROADSIDE - SEPTEMBER 19TH 1934 — DAY A black sedan carrying EDGAR and TWO OFFICERS is parked. watch through binoculars as -- A man leaves his house, wa around to his locked garage and disappears. The man re-emerges in his car -- a 1930 BLUE DODGE SEDAN. They tail him as he drives up Tremont Avenue. Traffic pic up. THEY LOSE SIGHT OF HIM FOR A MOMENT. When he comes ba into view, they see ANOTHER POLICEMAN HAS PULLED HIM OVER

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Pull over! The driver does. Edgar leaps out, runs to the car, and pu the other officer out of the way. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) FBI. Put your hands up. Edgar jams his gun in the car. The man inside puts his ha up, and in a truly innocent way, with a German accent ask

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN CAR
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Get out of the car. He does. The officers put him face first against the car. Edgar pulls the man’s ID and a $20 bill out of his wallet The bill has a gold marker on it. Edgar quickly checks it serial number using his MASTER LIST. It’s a match.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Bruno Hauptmann, you are under arrest for the kidnapping and murder of Charles Lindbergh Junior. And he’s cuffed. EXT. NEW JERSEY JAIL —- DAY FLASH! FLASH! The Press snaps photos of Hauptmann being escorted in. Edgar is front and center. Colonel Schwartzk (Lindbergh’s home earlier) is pushed off to the side. The FREEZE FRAME of this still crosses the cut to:  85. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Old Hoover is examining the same still as Agent Garrison' keys strike the paper, the pages are stacking up. A new c page reads, “UNTITLED FBI STORY.”

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: We need a title, Agent Garrison. Garrison just keeps typing. The phone rings. Hoover picks OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) We're working, Miss Gandy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The tape came in.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (perks up) Put it in my private office. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Hoover loops up a reel to reel audio tape. He treats it l a blown egg. Precious, fragile. He hits PLAY. At first the sounds are hard to make out. A DOOR CLOSING, FABRIC MOVING, CHIT CHAT, DRINKING. The wor are hard to distinguish, but it sounds like A FEW BLACK M AND TWO BLACK WOMAN. Hoover leans in, titillated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOCUS ON: the microphone under the bed. We see feet an shadows, but mostly it’s just sounds. (As Hoover hits fast forward, the film zooms forward and shadows move faster, returning to normal when he hits pla FAST FORWARD: talking. FAST FORWARD: Kissing. FAST FORWAR STOP / PLAY: It’s audio roulette. He hits the jackpot: th sound of THE BLACK MEN HAVING SEX WITH THE TWO BLACK WOME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover is listening, his forehead is misty, he may even b Masturbating, it’s tough to tell. The phone rings. He ign it. It rings again. He ignores it, trying to keep his foc It won’t stop ringing. He flies into a rage, and picks up phone -- without hitting stop on the tape player.  86.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I told you I’m not to be disturbed. INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE - SAME TIME Old Helen can hear the sex recording through the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover. It’s urgent. I have Agent Shakin on from Dallas.-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: GORDON SHANKLIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My apologies Mr. Hoover, I told Miss Gandy to put me right through.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: What is it, Agent, Shankin?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON SHANKLIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sir, the President has been shot. (Edgar is stunned) He was just declared dead, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Who knows about this?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON SHANKLIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one, sir. I thought you should know before the press reports it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Agent Shankin. He hangs up. Even steely Hoover has to process the magnit of this moment. He walks into his outer office, consideri his next move. He focuses in on his NOW COMPLETED REPLICA ROBERT KENNEDY'S FIREPLACE. He picks up his phone and dia OLD HOOVER (CONT ’D) Get me Robert Kennedy... I don’t care where in McLean he is. Put me through immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Kennedy walks up to his phone, relaxed, unaware.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT F. KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover?  87.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Kennedy, The President has been shot. Hoover hangs up. He eyes the red buzzer on his desk. He unscrews the bulb and the light goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flags are all at half staff for Kennedy. Hoover doesn seem to notice. He’s got his eye on the 6th race of the d Toulson is by his side. Both are using binoculars, both s as the horses round the end headed toward the home stretc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses round the corner 30 years earlier in Del Mar. REVEAL: Edgar and Clyde, dressed to the nines, watching a similar race. They’ve clearly made it to their vacation. Their horse wins! It’s pure joy. These two are being trea like royalty, surrounded by DESI ARNAZ, BING CROSBY, JIMM DURANTE, LUCILLE BALL, and A FEW MOBSTER TYPES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde changes into a robe and checks his hair. It takes v little for him to be handsome. He’s far more interested i his race stubs, his treasures. He places them carefully i zippered pouch of his dop kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar is in his own bathroom changing into a silk robe. H checks his hair, finds a grey and plucks it out. He slick the rest back. He brushes his teeth with precision and sp He walks out of his bathroom, through his bedroom, and in the central living room just as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Clyde enters from his own suite. Without words, Clyde p two cocktails. Edgar finds a radio station. Edgar turns and watches Clyde from behind, finishing thei drinks. It all feels very romantic.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Did you see his shoes?  88.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Desi Arnaz? The leather ones with the horrible buckles across the top? No didn’t notice them one bit.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: You’d think with all of their money they’d have better fashion sense, or pay someone to have it for them.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: And his fau-ginger wife, when she walked in, I was afraid a hunter might pull a rifle on that hat. Edgar imitates how it must have bounced each time she too step. Clyde is charmed. He sits. Edgar does the same. Cly puts his hand on Edgar’s. Edgar continues laughing for a - without taking his hand away. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) I care so very much for you, Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (gets up the nerve, then) I love you, Edgar. Edgar won’t look at Clyde -- who is looking right at him. YOUNG TOULSON (CONT’D) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes. Out of nerves or preparation, in the slightest of gesture Clyde wets his lip.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: c-Can I ask you s-something?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Anything. Edgar removes his hand to reach for a drink he doesn’t ne

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What do you think of Dorothy Lamour? The actress.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: With Rudy Vallee at the Stork Club?  89.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s the one.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: She’s a bit too camp for me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Well, I’m thinking... of t-t-taking her up on a proposal.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: For dinner?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. We’ve already had dinners.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: On the weekends. When I’ve gone up to New York.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (that feels like cheating) I see.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What I’m asking is... I think it may be time for a Mrs. Hoover. (Clyde can’t even speak) You don’t like her?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Don’t make a fool of me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (the big, scary question) Have you become... physical?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes. We have. (Toulson quietly fumes) You’d rather me be half a person, Clyde? Remain incomplete? Toulson throws his drink against a wall. Edgar shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: Am I an incompletion?  90.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Pick that glass up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: No. I won’t. I have no reason to. Fire me. Now. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You are making a fool of yourself. And Clyde clears two more glasses on the bar onto the flo There is glass everywhere. Edgar is speechless. YOUNG HOOVER (CONT’D) Clyde, and you have no shoes on. Stop this! Clyde gets up in Edgar’s face. It looks like he might fig him physically.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: You will never tell me what to do again. You just lost that right. I see through you. You’re a scared, heartless, horrible, little man. Edgar throws a punch. It lands. Toulson throws one of his own. It’s a brutal fight. Years of pent up attraction. They crash to the floor. Clyde pins Edgar. He considers pounding his face in. Instead, he kisses Edgar full on th lips. They hold for a moment. Edgar hardly resists. Final Clyde pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: (not meaning it) Don’t ever do that again.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: I won't. Clyde checks himself for cuts and starts out of the room. He’s almost to his bedroom when Edgar stops him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Don’t leave me, Clyde... Please. We have a second day of races. (hard words to form) I’m begging you.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON
dialogues.text: (a long beat, then) If you ever mention a lady friend (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TOULSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: again, that will be the last day you share my company. Clyde goes. Edgar touches his lips, recalling Clyde’s aga his. A sensation he may never feel again. He calms his shaking, gets up, and starts collecting glass off the flo The sound of a GUNSHOT -- crosses the cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picking up where the race left off before the flashback - flags still at half staff: --as the horses round the corner to the finish, Old Touls feels a numbness in his right shoulder. He blinks his eye he’s seeing flashes. He shifts as if tripping, as if the ground just moved, and he sits. Hoover rushes to his side do others around them.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: What is it, Clyde? (Clyde can’t answer) Get a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanked by TWO AGENTS and Miss Gandy, Hoover looks quite

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He should be able to recover most of his function, but a stroke like this will limit the hours he can work. The information he can process. For a while at least... Are you okay, Mr. Hoover?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I played in the yard with my dog on Saturday. Perhaps it’s dehydration.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: That could do it. But it may be wise to reduce your work hours as well. At your age it’s important to take leave.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Can I have some privacy please? The other Agents go. Hoover steams.  92. OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) If you ever denigrate me in front of my staff again, I will have you railroaded out of your profession.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (truly afraid) I apologize, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: What do you have for energy?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We have diet medications that tend to give a boost.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: So I could lose a few pounds and have more energy?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You don’t need to worry about your weight sir, it’s solid weight. It’s ass kissing, but Hoover appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: We’ll schedule a daily visit. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME / BREAKFAST TABLE - DAY Hoover and Toulson sit across from each other. Hoover tap hard boiled egg with a spoon and expertly peels it. Toulson struggles to grip his spoon. His entire right sid immobilized. His face droops. Hoover lets him struggle.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: They’re giving him the Nobel Prize. (Toulson nods.) The degenerates and radicals are being lifted up internationally. It’s like 1920 all over again.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Don't...

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: When he finds out we have this tape, that we know the truth about his character, he will decline the award.  93.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Johnson... Wait. He ignores Toulson’s plea, focusing instead on Toulson’s struggle. He gets up, leans in close and peels it for him

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I can’t understand you, Clyde. You have to work harder to enunciate. (Toulson looks concerned) We have no legal recourse. Law enforcement hasn’t kept pace with the improved tactics of today’s criminals.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: What’s the... idea.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: We have friends in the press. We plant stories with them to insure the activities of suspected radical leaders see the light of day.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: They’1l trace it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Only if they’re true. It’s Counter intelligence, Clyde. The more untrue the story, the more dramatic the impact. I’m going to deliver the hotel recording the day before the Nobel Prize with a personal letter. If he still accepts it. I’ll deliver the tape to the press.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: The tape may... not be legal.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s why the letter won’t be from me. It will be a fictitious letter from one of his own.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: There would be... no room for error. I’m not certain we could... insure that. Hoover doesn’t like the prudent advice or his “special friend’s” flagrant display of mortality.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I can’t understand you, Clyde. Hoover hits his own yolk. It’s hard. He tosses it down to dog who’s been waiting expectantly. OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) I need you back at the office tomorrow. It’s no time to relent.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: I can’t. It’s not the answer Hoover wanted. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY The doctor fills a syringe with amphetamines, leans in to Hoover’s arm, and slides the needle gently in. CLOSE ON: Old Hoover’s eyes dilate. He’s juiced. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Edgar is sitting at the typewriter himself now. Writing. hear the words. It’s manic, emotional, a drug induced tir

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look into your heart. You know you are a complete fraud and a great liability to all of us Negroes. (This is a fraudulent letter) White people in this country have enough frauds of their own but I am sure they don’t have one at this time that is anywhere near your equal. I repeat... (return key, return key) I repeat... you are a colossal fraud and an evil, vicious one at that. You could not believe in God... Clearly you don’t believe in any personal moral principles. (is this all self-reflection?) You have turned out to be not a leader, but a dissolute, abnormal moral imbecile. (he reflects, then) There is only one thing left for you to do. You know what it is... There is but one way out for you. You better take it before your (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: filthy, abnormal fraudulent self is bared to the nation. The letter is a bloody, inky tirade. He seals it in an envelope. It says as much about Hoover’s own state as it about the mysterious recipient. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Hoover is with a new writer, AGENT JONES. He almost looks black -- mixed race perhaps. Hoover is trying to process

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Miss Gandy told me you stopped with Bruno Hauptman’s arrest. Should we start there?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes... Check for his address in earlier drafts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hauptmann is handcuffed, standing in the middle of the ro His wife walks in. Edgar’s focus shifts from a pricey STROMBERG-CARLSON RADIO to her expensive shoes. Officers her from embracing her husband. She starts to cry. Hauptm tries to comfort her -- in German:

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Es ist nichts. Es ist Uber meine Gliicksspiel.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER ONE
dialogues.text: That this is about his gambling.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: May I sit? He knows he’s been caught in a lie. He sits by the window

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where’s the rest of his money?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you mean. Or who HE is.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: You don’t know who Charles Lindbergh is?  96.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Except maybe from the papers, no.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: This isn’t the kind of money a carpenter makes, Mr. Hauptmann.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: I made Wall Street investments. Agents in the adjoining room start ripping open Hauptman’ Mattress, but Hauptmann pays it no attention. He simply g out the window. Edgar takes note. He walks to the window, peers out, and sees the small, crude, garage fifty feet a INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S GARAGE - LATER Agents tear up the floorboards in the garage. They find f dirt, grab a shovel, and dig into it and quickly find a j buried in a hole, but it is only filled with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar stands in front of Hauptmann holding the empty jar.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where is the ransom money, Bruno? Did you spend it all on your old lady’s shoe collection? His wife Anna’s shoes are in a pile in the middle of the floor. She’s having a nervous breakdown. Agents start carting out stacks of Hauptman’s papers, fil with his handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Where are you taking my things?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: To the FBI, Mr. Hauptmann. Does that worry you?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: You hunt the wrong man because I have accent, because you don’t trust immigrant. You are a bigot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENTS cuff Hauptman to a chair. A NYPD OFFICER has a ham The lights go out. We hear punches, blows and screams.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mass of Hauptman’s papers and journals have arrived. Albert Osborne (the handwriting expert from earlier) is t to receive them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert Osborne is isolated on a riser with 11x14 photosta blow ups of letters and words from Hauptman’s writings.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT S. OSBORNE
dialogues.text: In both the ransom note and Mr. Hauptmann’s personal writings, he wrote, “haus” for house, “anyding” for anything,”gut” for good,” and “boad” for boat, And notice the inverted capital “N”s and “y”s that look like “j"s INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 With the mixed race agent.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: But couldn’t those sorts of Germanic formations come from any number of immigrants? Aren’t those common translation mistakes?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: You're right, Agent Jones. Alone it wouldn’t have been enough. So when my agents arrived to replace the local police, we searched again. INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S GARAGE - DAY - 1934 FBI AGENTS are literally dismantling the garage. EDGAR IS STANDING WATCH. The NYC Police simply observe. Edgar is focused on a piece of wood he finds odd. It’s above the w bench -- a board nailed across two joists.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: What purpose would a piece of wood like this serve? REVEAL: wood expert Koehler is now there too.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t appear structural.  98. JUMP TO: AGENTS carefully pull the board off the joists, waiting to see if anything gives structurally. It doesn’t Behind it they finds TWO NEWSPAPER PACKETS. Edgar opens o carefully. Inside are ONE HUNDRED TEN-DOLLAR GOLD NOTES.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER
dialogues.text: Remove all the joists. JUMP TO: ANOTHER AGENT finds a hidden shelf. In it is a O GALLON SHELLAC CAN. He pulls out the rags stuffed on top. Inside is $11,930 worth of ransom money. AT THE SAME TIME: Arthur Koehler finds Hauptman’s tool ch He opens it. It’s neat and organized. All of the tools ar place, except: the STANDARD 3/4 INCH CHISEL. He pulls Hauptman’s saw from the chest and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same space the handwriting expert appeared in earlier now Arthur Koehler is explaining his own findings.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: You see, no two saws make the same markings. This saw from Bruno Hauptmann’s tool chest makes markings identical to those found on the ladder used in the crime. I searched 1900-- (holds up a piece of wood) --factories across the country to see which blade made the other cuts on the ladder. I narrowed it down to one. Centralia lumber yard. Four blocks from Mr. Hauptman’s home. CLOSE ON: Edgar listens from a bench, seemingly alone, gi with this man’s scientific exactitude. INT. BRUNO HAUPTMAN’S ATTIC - NIGHT Edgar is with Agent Sisk and Arthur Koehler as they appro an attic corner and see -- an eight foot board is missing Koehler unwraps a long bag labeled -- “Rail 16.” It’s the original rail he pointed out to Edgar in the lab so long

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rail 16. It didn’t match the rest. And those extra holes. Why were they there?  99. He lays the wood next to the empty spot in the floor. It’ perfect match. The four extra holes match perfectly with nail holes in the floor joists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is still in the white space.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR KOEHLER
dialogues.text: The science is conclusive. Mr. Hauptmann built the ladder. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 The young, mixed race FBI Agent stops typing.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: But did he do it alone?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (displeased with the question) He never confessed, but what sociopath ever does. The evidence was clear. He was indicted for murder in the first degree while perpetrating a burglary. In New Jersey, that is punishable by death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two story, neo-colonial building stands strong with f columns out front. Snow has turned the streets white. Hundreds of telegraph and teletype wires run out an upper window onto an overwhelmed utility pole. From there, the wires fan out, carrying their messages to the entire worl The streets are filled with CARS, REPORTERS, and EAGER CITIZENS. A MAN sells miniature replicas of the kidnapper ladder on green ribbon necklaces. ANOTHER MAN hocks packe of curly blonde hair (that looks a lot like his own) for bucks a pop claiming it’s “Baby Lindy’s.” In a makeshift radio studio in the back of a truck, an announcer reports:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: January 2nd, 1935, a cold winter morning in Fleming New Jersey, and what has now undoubtedly been penned “The Trial of the Century” has begun. H.L. Mencken has called it, “the biggest story since the (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: resurrection.” And from the looks of things, it may be bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL: this is the space the EXPERT AGENTS have been TESTIFYING from. As in the earlier sequences, Edgar is th listening intently from his bench, dressed to the nines. NOW WE REVEAL: he’s not alone. The courtroom is packed wi REPORTERS and ONLOOKERS. From their dress and entourage, clear many are rich and/or famous. The prosecutor, WILENTZ, calls his next witness:

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: Your honor, I would like to call to the stand Mr. Charles Lindbergh. In a gray suit and shirt with a tie, Charles Lindbergh wa slowly and confidently up to the stand and takes the seat next to THE JUDGE. The room is hushed. Lindbergh looks through the crowd, to the defense stand, stopping on Anna Hauptmann. He remains calm, unreadable. WILENTZ (CONT’D) Picking up where you left off. You said you heard a voice, in the cemetary that night.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: Yes. Very clearly. A voice coming from the cemetary, to the best of my belief, calling Dr. Condon. In a foreign accent, “Hey, Doctor.”

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: And since that time, have you heard the same voice?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: Yes, I have.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: And whose voice was it, Colonel, that you heard in the vicinity of St. Raymond’s Cemetery that night, saying, “Hey Doctor?” And for the first time, Lindbergh turns his gaze from Wil -- to Bruno Hauptmann. Emotionless, Strong:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH
dialogues.text: That was Hauptman’s voice.  101. Hauptmann locks eyes with Lindbergh. They hold their gaze for a moment. The air goes out of the room. Lindbergh loo back to Wilentz and A GASP RUNS THROUGH THE ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK
dialogues.text: Mr. Bruno Hauptmann, take the stand. We see A REPORTER who’s snuck a tiny film camera in under coat. He furtively aims it at the witness stand. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Agent Jones watches Hoover pulls the shades. The room goe dark. Hoover fires up a film projector... It’s B&W footag Hauptmann from the trial itself. Hauptmann is on the stand being questioned. He’s combativ arrogant, and easily bothered:

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: You have had an opportunity in this court today to tell the whole truth. Have you told the truth?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMANN
dialogues.text: I told the truth already.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: And the statements you made to District Attorney Foley, did you tell him the whole truth?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMANN
dialogues.text: To a certain extent

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: And to a certain extent you didn't tell him the truth, is that it? Silence from Hauptmann.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This board that came from your closet, S-204, has these numbers here. It is a little blurred now, isn't it?  102.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: It looks like 2974, and the numbers down here, 3-7154, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: And between those numbers are some words, it looks like "Decatur" and "Sedgwick", you see that? You know what that means don't you, that address on there?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: It is Dr. Condon's address and telephone number. The man who paid the ransom. Written in your writing on a board in your closet.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when you saw this piece of wood you said, "That's my lumber." Isn't that so - in the Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: I said, "Yes," without thinking.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: You don't usually do things without thinking. You have a very good mind, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO HAUPTMAN
dialogues.text: I don't think so, not so good.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: Oh, you really DO think so, don't you? Wilentz has just called him a liar and manipulator. Hauptman’s silence speaks volumes. The projector winds ou  103. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Hoover takes A FIST FULL OF PILLS. AND GETS MORE SHOTS -- WE SEE -- ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE OF: Martin Luther King’s march Washington and his famous, “I Have a Dream,” speech -- as it’s going on right outside -- it likely is. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY The curtains are still drawn. The room is still dark. Hoo is high on amphetamines again. Agent Jones is packing up.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: A man’s legacy is determined by where the story ends. Lets consider that tonight and make a decision tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Is this about a man’s legacy or about an institution’s reputation?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The two are connected Agent Jones. One invented the other. And vice- versa

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Agent Jones goes. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME / LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Hoover sits watching the nightly news with Toulson. Touls is doing better. Walking around.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: There’s a new restaurant in the hotel in Miami. We could go. I could make the arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Would you please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: I’m feeling better. If you’d like, I could return home.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Stay and watch with me. (Toulson sits) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He received my letter with the audio tape last night. (Toulson is quiet) Say it Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: It’s so risky. Over a few negative news articles, Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: He’s deliberately allowed himself to be surrounded by Communists. With the power he’s gathered he’s now the greatest domestic threat-- Edgar turns up the volume. He focuses in on: a chiron. “SWEDEN - NOBEL PEACE PRIZE” OLD HOOVER (CONT’D) He’1l decline the award. He knows what we have could ruin him. There is no question. He’s done, Clyde. Hoover stops breathing. He can’t hear the reporter. He’s focused on the grainy B&W image of MARTIN LUTHER KING bei handed the Nobel Peace Prize. And then his words:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN LUTHER KING
dialogues.text: (on TV) I accept the Nobel Prize for Peace at a moment when 22 million Negroes of the United States of America are engaged in a creative battle to end the long night of racial injustice. (a jump cut) --all the people of the world will have to discover a way to live together in peace... man must evolve a method which rejects revenge, aggression and retaliation. (a jump cut) I believe that unarmed truth and unconditional love will have the final word in reality. This is why right temporarily defeated is stronger than evil triumphant. I believe that what self-centered men have torn down, men other-centered can build up. It’s now clear that the man Hoover’s been after this whol time is King. It’s also clear Hoover’s lost this round. H shuts off the TV. Shamed.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell tolls atop the old courthouse. A crowd outside cha

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Kill Hauptmann! Kill Hauptmann!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
