dialogues.text: Their chants can be heard as Hauptmann is ushered in wear mManacles by a STATE TROOPER and FIVE POLICEMEN. He sits. Edgar watches the Jurors enter. None look at Mr. Hauptman

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Would the jury and the defendant rise. (they do) Mr. Foreman, what say you? Do you find the defendant guilty or not guilty?

dialogues.speaker: JURY FOREMAN
dialogues.text: We the jury find the defendant, Richard Bruno Hauptmann guilty of murder in the first degree. MESSENGER BOYS head for the doors. Guards block them. Edg holds his breath.

dialogues.speaker: WILENTZ
dialogues.text: Your honor, I move for immediate sentencing. Edgar watches Hauptmann intently. The Judge does the same

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE TRENCHARD
dialogues.text: According to the law of this state, I rule that Mr. Bruno Hauptmann suffer death at the time and place, and in the manner provided by law. Edgar watches Hauptmann go white as a ghost. Hauptman’s w watches the floor, refusing to look at her husband. Her t fall to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG BOY leans out the 2nd story window of the courtho

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: It’s death for Bruno Hauptmann! And THE CROW ROARS. It’s a lynching mob.  106. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT Edgar sits on the corner of his mom’s bed cutting out his PRESS CLIPPINGS announcing the trial’s conclusion. He pas one in an album. ANGLE ON: his mother. She’s so ill she c sit up in bed. He now must clip the articles himself. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY - 1964 Hoover is with Agent Jones again.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The trial of the century. The criminal shamed. The FBI cemented as the public hero... It’s our ending.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: But did he act alone? Is he the one who actually took the child from the crib? How can you be sure?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The mountain of evidence we discovered, uncovered, clarified and confirmed. You can’t dispute it.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: Clarence Darrow did.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Of course. That’s what he does.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: And Mrs. Roosevelt issued a public statement questioning his guilt.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Jones. She has plenty to hide herself when it comes to un- American activities.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT JONES
dialogues.text: If you’re comfortable with it as an ending, I’ll do my best with it. If Hoover was feeling better he would fire him, but he’s feeling very weak. The phone rings. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: Ben Bradlee of Newsweek is waiting in the meeting room, sir.  107.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The doctor first, Miss Gandy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDY
dialogues.text: He’s in Baltimore, Mr. Hoover. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Hoover is in his office with BEN BRADLEE of NEWSWEEK. Hoover hits stop on the recording of King and the woman i the hotel room. He’s fighting exhaustion, trying to be wa

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: If you want it, it’s yours exclusively.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I heard you took it to the Post already. Nobody’s interested, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The public would be. And they deserve to know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: The public might be curious. But with all due respect, I’m not sure it’s of serious interest.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: The SCLC has direct ties to communism, Mr. Bradlee. We are seeing a pervasive contempt for law and order. The crime rate it soaring, there is widespread, open defiance of authority, and mark my words, if this goes unchecked, it will once again plunge our Nation into the abyss of anarchy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’ve found no connection between Mr. King and the Communist party.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Even great men can be corrupted. Communism is not a political party. It is a disease anyone can catch if not careful. And it spreads and it corrupts the soul, turning the (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: gentlest of men into villainous tyrants.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: He preaches peace.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: It always starts peacefully. It’s a ruse. Mr. Bradlee, when the country is taken by surprise, you won’t be able to live with yourself knowing you could have prevented the bombings and violence.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I appreciate you bringing this to me, Edgar. I’1l consider it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (pleased) I can tell you are interested, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. But I’1l be candid, Edgar. I’m more interested in what this says about you and your FBI.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: If you’re going to be candid, Ben. Be candid.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You know the funny thing about notoriety? Especially the kind that needs adoration, fame for fame’s sake? If unchecked, it inevitably leads to villainy... infamy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Exactly. And I’ve worked too hard to watch the bad guys capture the spotlight again.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BRADLEE
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, I suggest you look into what this squabble with Mr. King is really about before you destroy the reputation of the thing we both know you love the most. A beat between them. Hoover is stung. Stunned.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s 8:44 on April 3, 1936. The execution room is brightl lit. Hauptmann is ushered in and strapped into the chair.

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTION SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Bruno Hauptmann. Do you have any final words? Hauptmann remains silent. They slip a mask over his head. lever is flipped, his body jerks, and smoke rises from hi head. A beat, then the electricity is shut off. A Doctor approaches the body and checks the pulse.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Bruno Hauptmann is dead as of 8:47, Friday April 3rd, 1936. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - NIGHT A terrified Edgar sits next to his mother watching her breathing grow shallow, his brother and family around her His mother takes her last breath. A doctor closes her eye Edgar cannot process the moment. He’s in shock. INT. HOOVER’S CHILDHOOD HOME - LATER THAT NIGHT Edgar is in shock, lost in the only home he’s ever known. gathers the many albums filled with clippings, opens the oldest one, then stops heartbroken. He goes to her jewelr case -- GRABS UP HER PEARLS, AND HOLDS THEM TO HIS CHEST. JUMP TO: Edgar slips his mother’s old dress over his head He’s gained some weight and it almost fits. He pulls on h mother’s pearls and fixes them just the way she would. Inspecting himself in the mirror, Edgar has his first and only complete emotional breakdown of the film. This was t closest thing to love he’d known. INT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE / LATE 60'S MONTAGE - DAY WE’RE IN HOOVER’S MIND: Quick cuts of NEWS EVENTS are intercut with Hoover getting more amphetamine shots. Each time his pupils dilate, we see: King being shot, gunfire a clock tower, war in Vietnam, injured returning Soldiers AN EVEN OLDER HOOVER gets up from his chair. He seems dru out of his mind. He walks to the window. Outside there is parade. He steps out onto the balcony, the sun in his eye  110. He looks down just in time to see the presidential motorc It’s the inauguration of Richard Nixon. He looks out to the mall in the distance. He can see an o of anti-war protestors. This isn’t the country he’s known HE’S A STRANGER IN HIS OWN LAND. EXT. NIXON’S OFFICE - DAY Hoover sits outside Nixon’s office. IT’S THE EXACT SAME S AS WHEN HE DID THE SAME AFTER ROOSEVELT’S INAUGURATION -- JUST 40 YEARS LATER He even holds a file on his lap. This game should be old hat by now -- so why is he sweating?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The President is ready for you, Mr. Hoover. And Hoover walks in, just like he did forty years earlier

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen walks the now ultra (70’s) modern hallways of the F This place has certainly grown and matured -- even from t 60’s version we first saw at the film’s opening. The FBI appears to be a well oiled technological wonder. EXT. HOOVER’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Helen walks through the outer office to Hoover's inner of door. She knocks. Nothing. She knocks again. Nothing. She listens. She can hear stilted breathing. She considers fo beat, then does what she never has, she opens the door. Her boss looks up to her from his desk. He’s been Sobbing

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Mr. Hoover, you weren’t answering your phone... You had a photo session with a retiring Agent. He’s leaving now. And she starts out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Where’s Clyde?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: It’s a “bad day” for him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Can you schedule a dinner for him and I... our old corner booth?  lll.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid he’s too tired today... Perhaps you could dine at his house. I think he’d like that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Helen?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: (surprised at the familiarity) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Do I kill everything I love?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: (carefully) He’s not gone yet, Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: (absorbs it, then) And everything we’ve built?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: (by rote) No. The Bureau is stronger than just you and me now. Your child is sure, and keeps this country safe.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Helen, if anything happens to me, I need you to do something.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Nixon will come for it all. They’ll crucify me and my Bureau. I’m afraid of what will happen if I’m not here to protect it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Your private files, sir? (he nods) Then no one will never find them.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: No matter what pressure is put on?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HELEN GANDRY
dialogues.text: Yes, Edgar. I promise you.  112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SAME SHOT WE SAW YEARS BEFORE: Old Hoover leaves work walking the long hallway toward the elevators, Agents stepping out of his way. An old, emaciated Toulson is far behind, dragging his right leg, struggling to keep up. Ho refuses to acknowledge his dearest partner's impairment. INT. TOULSON’S HOUSE - NIGHT Hoover sits in the unfamiliar dining room with his nearly blind friend, eating OMAHA STEAK and baked potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Did he ask for your resignation?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: He asked what I had in the files on him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: “What file, sir?” But he knows. He asked me to expand our wiretaps to cover news reporters.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: We can’t do that. Especially now.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: That’s the problem, Clyde. If I won't do his “Black Bag” jobs, he’ll create his own private force.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: That's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: He didn’t say it. I could see it in his eyes. He won’t be controlled. He’1l do anything to hold onto power... He’s a menace.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: (the irony hurts) Right. I see.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I NEVER played his game. If to some it seemed like rule bending, then perhaps they need to look into (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: their souls and consider what it is they did that made them feel blackmailed and intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: I wasn’t thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: I was thinking it might be time for us to retire. I don’t know how much longer I have.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Shut up, Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: You built a great thing, Edgar. If you stop now, you’d be celebrated. That’s what you want, isn’t it? Our country’s adoration? There’s a chance you could have it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: And why wouldn’t I have it?! I saved this country from Bolshevik invasion, rid us of radicals, captured Machine Gun Kelley, killed Dilinger, arrested Karpis, convicted Bruno Hauptmann, and now when I try with my last breath to save this country again, I am rewarded with a forced retirement? No. I will not go down to this man. And your suggestion that I do makes me question your very loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: MY loyalty, Edgar?! Hoover knows he’s gone too far. He puts his hand to his c like he has indigestion. Avoiding Toulson’s glare. OLD TOULSON (CONT’D) (serving up the hard truth) I read your manuscript, Edgar. (Hoover looks up.) You didn’t arrest Karpis. You know as well as I do there was no white horse in the street, no gun--  114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPLAY OF THE EARLIER KARPIS ARREST -- This time Edgar doesn’t lead the charge. Karpis simply walks out of the building, and is surrounded by armed FBI Agents. Only whe it’s safe does Edgar emerges from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: --in the back seat. And YOU didn’t kill Dilinger. Agent Purvis did-- INT. HOOVER’S OUTER OFFICE - 1971 CLOSE ON: Dilinger’s death mask, pipe and glasses on disp

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --but you kept the glory for yourself. And Machine Gun Kelly never said, “Don’t Shoot G-men.” You made it up for the comics. INT. TOULSON’S HOUSE - NIGHT -— CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: And when we went to the scene of the “greatest crime of the century,” Mr. Lindbergh didn’t come out and-- EXT. CHARLES LINDBERGH’S HOME - DAY - 193 UNLIKE THE EARLIER VERSION -- Edgar gets in his car, his on Lindbergh in his upper window, refusing to even make e contact with Edgar and Clyde on the driveway below.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: --shake your hand and express his faith in the FBI. He called you a “fussy little man” and refused to even meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPLAY OF HAUPTMANN’S ARREST: This time it’s not Edgar making the bust, it’s Agent Sisk

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t arrest Hauptmann. Agent Sisk did. You weren’t even at the scene. Just the photo-op. INT. TOULSON’S HOUSE - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS In atypical fashion, Hoover is silent. He knows it’s true  115.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Most of what you wrote was exaggeration. The rest lies, and I don’t know if you even realize it anymore. (Hoover looks i11) Edgar? You can lie to everyone else. The whole world. For your own sake, for the sake of the Bureau. But you CANNOT lie to me. Hoover is sweating. Toulson hands him a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: I should never have given you a job. You know that, Clyde? You weren’t qualified. (Toulson readies for an attack) Do you remember what you did in your interview?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: You fixed my window... And you found my handkerchief on the floor. And you handed it to me... Do you know why I was sweating?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Because you were exercising. And Hoover dabs his forehead with Toulson’s handkerchief. Toulson doesn’t interrupt, he refolds the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: No. That was also a lie... I was sweating because I knew that I needed you... I’ve never needed anyone else in my entire life. Not like that. And I started to perspire.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: (a long beat, then) I know... Hoover puts a hand on his chest, likely feigning indigest - perhaps wanting a way out of this affectionate moment. OLD TOULSON (CONT’D) Are you okay?  116.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Yes. Indigestion... Would you like to have dinner tomorrow night? At our old place?

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: (he knows he can’t) Perhaps if I feel better.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HOOVER
dialogues.text: Then you must. We have a good many things to discuss. I can’t depend on anyone at the Bureau now. And in his boldest show of affection in the film, Hoover kisses Toulson’s forehead, holding his lips there for som time. Toulson grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TOULSON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Edgar. And Hoover goes, trying to remain “J. Edgar Hoover” despi the feelings rising up inside him. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME - THAT NIGHT Hoover walks into his home. Something seems off, but he c figure it out. He plays with HIS DOGS. They lead him to a portrait of hi Mom. It seems she is making eye contact with him. He considers taking her down, but instead, straightens her. all is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Nixon is with his Chief of staff H.R. HALDEMAN. H just gotten a piece of juicy news. He’s stunned.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! That old cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: H.R. HALDEMAN
dialogues.text: I’‘ll get a speech prepared. We should go on Television.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON
dialogues.text: Not yet. First seal off his office. Change the locks. Do whatever you have to. I want those fucking files.  117. INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE —- MORNING Helen shows up to work as usual. Cool as Ice. Her phone rings. She takes the call in stride, and makes a simple n in her ledger -- “CALL: HOOVER HOUSEKEEPER. ANNIE.” She walks back to her office door, and closes it. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME - MORNING Old Toulson struggles up the stairs behind A MAID. When t reach Hoover’s bedroom door, she stops. She’s not going i Toulson takes a beat, considers the door. He’s never been the room. He pushes it open. REVEAL: it’s filled with Min vases, porcelain Foo dogs, Buddhas, ivory elephants, AND MULTITUDE OF NUDE MALE STATUES displayed on mahogany tabl draped in lace. This is Hoover’s hidden world. Any light might try and get in is blocked by Chinese screens. And there, lying on the floor in his silk pajama bottoms the body of J. Edgar Hoover. Toulson kneels next to the b and lovingly closes his eyes. Hoover has passed. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME / BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Toulson finds a stack of files sitting on the bedside tab On top is the manuscript of his unfinished book. He picks up. Under it is the King’s sex tape transcript, and a fol labeled “Eleanor Roosevelt.” He opens it and pulls out a photostat of a letter. As he reads it, we hear a replay o Young Edgar reading it years ago.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HOOVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Funny how even the dearest face will fade away in time. Most clearly I remember your eyes, with a kind of teasing smile in them, and the feeling of that soft spot just northeast of the corner of your mouth against my lips.” It’s the lesbian love letter to Eleanor that Edgar once rolled with laughter at. It seems he liked to keep it clo and read it often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broadcast of the President

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It can truly be said of him that he was a legend in his own time.--  118. INT. HOOVER’S OUTER AND INNER OFFICES - SAME TIME NIXON’S MEN barge into Hoover’s old office, seal it off, search for his secret files. They stand guard at the door not letting anyone in or out.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --His magnificent contribution to making this a great and good nation will be remembered by the American people long after the petty carpings and vicious criticisms of his detractors are forgotten. INT. HELEN GANDY’S OFFICE - SAME TIME It’s too late. Helen already has her boss’s private filin cabinets safely in her office. And as the President’s men search Hoover’s office and change his locks, she quietly the last of his files into the shredder.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The FBI he literally created and built is today universally regarded as the finest law-enforcement agency in the world. INT. HOOVER’S ADULTHOOD HOME / BEDROOM - DAY Toulson lays down in Hoover’s untouched bed, holding the Eleanor Roosevelt letter close to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD NIXON
dialogues.text: The FBI is the eternal monument honoring this great American. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARDS ON BLACK
dialogues.text: The contents of Hoover’s “private and personal” files wil never be known. Only a few clues from misfiled items have ever surfaced. Clyde Toulson inherited Hoover's estate, moved into his house, and accepted the U.S. flag draped over his coffin. Clyde Toulson's grave is a few yards from Hoover's in the Congressional Cemetery.
